story:
PORT  CAPA

An Installation Performance

Automatons, kinetic sculptures, and a surprising landscape filled with layers in motion take an audience through an archeological exploration of exciting dimensions at the Angeles Gate Cultural Center. Located on a magical hill in San Pedro, CA, overlooking the Port of Los Angeles, Sunken City, and the periphery of the urban world, this performance, on two years of research, stems from a CalArts collaboration. PORT CAPA is the second phase of a performance project that intersects industrial automation, thresholds, and possible futures.

 

PORT CAPA is proud to be a part of PST LA/LA: a celebration beyond borders, a far-reaching and ambitious exploration of Latin American and Latino art in dialogue with Los Angeles. Led by the Getty, Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA is the latest collaborative effort from arts institutions across Southern California.

Venue: Angels Gate Cultural Center

PORT CAPA is part of Coastal/Border  at Angels Gate Cultural Center, an exhibition of original site-responsive performance and installation work with corresponding public programming curated by Raquel Gutiérrez and Martabel Wasserman. 

Angels Gate Cultural Center provides a space for artists to work and engages community through arts education, exhibitions of contemporary art, and cultural events. Angels Gate is a non-grantee participant of PST LA/LA, which is why PORT CAPA depends on grassroots fundraising and why we are counting on your support.

PORT CAPA entrance is FREE and all are welcome! 

 

Fundraising Campaign

This is where you come in!

In an effort to make this dream come true, we are seeking support to:

  • Purchase and rent production materials including costumes, props, and sculptural materials.
  • Compensate 10 artists for their commitment and dedication to the project
  • Scenic shop rental used to build our novel scenic pieces

The Dreamiest of Teams

  • The design, production, and performance team is composed of art students and working artist in the Los Angeles area. As a truly interdisciplinary group, this project brings together the disciplines of theater, video, lighting, sound, and critical studies.

  • PORT CAPA is guided by Dany Naierman, a Venezuelan artist and recent graduate of the CalArts MA in Aesthetics and Politics. His work seeks to explore landscapes and the layers of history that appear invisible but live in the architectures and infrastructures of time and space. 
  • The main goal of this campaign is to support artists who have worked on the project for over a year. With the funds from this campaign, the artists in this collaboration will gain access to the basic materials required for a successful project, and they will receive a modest stipend for their work. Every person involved in this project has given and incredible amount of passion and dedication, and we hope to foment the essential value of art practitioners in the world.  

We believe in our work and are eager to make it a magical and important experience that will ignite new discourse and thrill the audience. 

And in the future, keep an eye out for PORT CAPA in a port near you!

Thank you for your essential support.

The PORT CAPA team.

story:
Short Summary

I have been teaching Mythology for nearly a decade and I now have enough to say on the subject to fill a book. Or two or three.  But we're starting with one: Myth Education. 

There are a lot of books on the subject, so what makes Myth Education unique?

A lot of books on mythology suffer from one of two problems, either (1) being too dry and esoteric or (2) being sanitized to appeal to a younger audience.  Myth Education takes the middle path and is accessible to anyone (whether they've studied mythology for years or have only seen a Thor movie) but remains honest about the original stories and characters -- warts and all.  Sex and violence are necessary components to many myths and I don't believe in sanitizing them away. Myth Education is for adults, not for kindergartners. But, anyone who can handle a PG13 movie should be able to handle this book just fine.

The other element that will make this book stand out and the reason for this campaign is the art. Myth Education presents a unique approach to these stories and characters that is both entertaining and informative, but the words are only part of it. With help from your donations I will be able to commission work from a bevy of artists to create original art that will make this book truly stand out from the crowd.  I teach at an art school and have seen the kind of work these stories and characters inspire and more importantly, I've learned that artists need to be paid.  I refuse to ask other people to work for the sake of "exposure" or the promise of payment later on.  Artists need to be paid.  And if we can pay them we'll get some tremendous work to accompany the text.  

What We Need & What You Get

We have secured a publisher. It's a small press publisher, but Myth Education will be available on at least three continents and in several digital formats. But, in order to make it as exciting to look at as it is to read I need help raising money to hire artists.  The more money we raise the more art we'll be able to commission -- any additional money not spent on art will be put toward marketing so your donations will have a very real effect on both the quality and success of this book.  And if this book does well I have several others in the works.

Perks for donors include getting your name listed in the special thanks and free copies of the final product as well as the opportunity to select a mythic figure you'd like to see featured in the book and to have that piece dedicated to you (or someone else of your choosing), and you can get yourself a printed copy of some of the original artwork created for the book.  And, most importantly (and most improbably) for one donation of $10,000 I will personally worship you as my personal god for one year, making sacrifices of animal crackers on an altar.  I mean, who wouldn't want that?

If we meet our goal of $2,000 the book will feature some spectacular art.  If we exceed the goal it'll mean more and more art, some additional marketing and (depending on how much we raise) it'll lay the ground work for the publication of more books by me.  

The Impact

I love mythology. I love writing about it, I love studying it, I love teaching it. It is beautiful and upsetting and hilarious.  And I think there is tremendous value in knowing the stories and characters that have helped shape both our culture and our minds. We better understand the past and the present through looking at the mythologies of the world. This is the shared cultural history of humanity. And making it not just accessible but vibrant for a modern audience is how we can best celebrate that. With your help, Myth Education can be that celebration. 

Other Ways You Can Help

For those of you who are interested in this book or mythology or creative endeavors in general but are not able to make a donation there is still plenty of ways you can help.  

Share the links. Share them again and again.  Indiegogo makes it very easy. Just click on one of many links and share it on Facebook, Twitter or whatever social media you have.  Donations are great, but the only way to get people to make donations is to make sure they know about the campaign. So share it. Pass it on. Put this campaign on your wedding registry (congratulations!) or in your obituary (condolences!) or anything else you can think of. The more people know about it the more we'll be able to raise and the better the final product will be.

The more people know about it the more we'll be able to raise and the better the final product will be.

story:
To Inspire

transform, discover, connect to the world

To Dream

It's been a year long journey that lead to this

a little autobiography:

Stephen Wawryk is a yogi, who some may call an old soul. Stories of him performing courageous acts of love include when he jumped in front of a moving car at the speed of 40mph, to save his mini dachshund, Polka Dot. Another on his wedding day, when he swept the love of his life, Ana, off her feet by getting his group of friends together to sing and play a rendition of "The Girl" by City and Colour.

Then on November 20, 2015 he received a phone call from his mom, telling him that his dad had unexpectedly passed away. Flying out that morning and writing the eulogy on the plane, he spoke in front of hundreds of friends and family members to share what he believed the message to be learned. To notice the little things, appreciate what you have, and never stop dreaming.

 

Spending the next 7 weeks in New York, he took a snowboarding trip with his Uncle Mike. During a lunch conversation, he discovered that his cousin had been drawing for art school, and that is when it clicked. 

Not knowing this would lead to Unknown, he partnered with Michaela Wawryk, to hand draw the pictures for a mindfulness book he envisioned on back when he was in Ojai, California. A true spirit in her form, Michaela has expressed the creative influence, vulnerability, and drive in all creation through the artwork featured in the book.

To Accept

Mindfulness has been growing in popularity

Mindfulness can be described for when you bring awareness to what you're doing, and the world around you. It allows you to live in the present moment, while decluttering your mind from future angsts and previous defeats. It gives you serenity, because no pain can be felt when you are in this state.

Think of the book Unknown as a detox for your mind.

These small reminders will bring you back to the amazing being that you are. They will help you explore your purpose as a child of God. After reading Unknown, you will live the life you've wanted, and discover that we are all creative and free.

To Impact

Stephen Wawryk, author of the book, has experience working in distribution and the consumer product goods industry. Since moving to Los Angeles, he has worked with tech startups, and is currently managing timelines, projects, and events with a nonprofit.

The campaign goal will be used for printing a minimum order, print materials, ISBN number and barcode, copyright, shipping, and packaging.

For each additional book sold thereafter, half the proceeds will be donated to the LA Food Bank, to help provide food for those in less fortunate circumstances this holiday season.

A special thanks to Michaela Wawryk, Chris Schneekluth, and Eric Blank for all your hard work in making the book Unknown come to life. You are all so amazingly skilled in what you do, and this would not have been possible without each of you.

New York, Seattle, and Los Angeles unite! Thank you for your support.

bookunknown.com

story:
Brief history of the project

My name is Pietro Fedele, 26, from Pescara, Italy. 

After attending the Art School, I got a degree in industrial design that allowed me to delve into modelling studies and a master's degree in multimedia design thanks to which I have been involved in the study of Exhibit Design. My studies led me to become a drawer, a multimedia and industrial designer, and they have done nothing but suggesting me the means to tell the stories that I deem are worth telling. Today’s story is on the refugees.

It is urgent to tell this story!

Nowadays we hear about them every day, everywhere, but the image that flashed continually in my head and asked to be expressed, was that of a mass of people without identity. They are just the refugees, the nameless, the rescued, the migrants, the invaders… and I said to myself: I must tell their story!

Interviews? Reportage? Photographs? None of that. What I wanted to realize was instead an itinerant art installation, in motion, as are refugees.

The subject I wanted to deal was that of identity and of political, social and geographical barriers.

The Art Installations

The first installation will be held in the streets of the city center, where small groups of mannequins without a body, but just "floating" clothes standing in significant poses will be exposed without specific description.

 «Who are they?» I hope, passers-by will wonder this when looking at these tragic and quiet figures that, perhaps only by their clothing, will recall the refugees.

I removed the vowels from the title, just as I removed the identity from the figures.

Subsequent installations  will take place inside the covered market of piazza Muzii in Pescara, at the charity event organized by AVSI. 

In the second installation figures "hanging from a fence with barbed" appear. They recall the anguished “climbings” on border barriers. When we see the pictures taken on site, these figures - that I will purposely call the hung - seem still, impotent, crucified, dramatic. A ragged semi-transparent tarp stands between the visitors and the work: another barrier, a translucent curtain full of meanings. 

In the third installation  a sole figure, there is a migrant with his hands tied behind his back. He is wearing a life belt which is, in turn, surrounded by a ring of barbed wire. His feet are in the Mediterranean Sea, represented on a map of Europe on the ground. The life belt gives only the illusion of saving but its tied arms, giving a sense of helplessness, the barbed wire and the geographic barriers are real constraints that make these crossings: “the crossings of death”.

In the fourth, a group of refugees is covered, harnessed, cold, seated, surrendered on a mattress, oars in hand, as if they were on a raft. Around them there are barbed barriers with slogans inciting to shutting and rejection.

The event in Pescara will just be the springboard for an exhibition that will travel to other cities, whose municipalities or non-profit and cultural associations will decide to host the installations and continue sharing with us the project.

WHY TAKING PART TO THE FUND RAISING 

I think making this project is worth especially for a reason: there is a need for awareness-raising and art is the best way to do that because a work of art never holds a single shareable or not shareable message, but opens to a deeper reading, raises questions, remains engraved in the mind, thus generating a reflection.

For this reason, I ask you to help me in carrying out this work by participating in the crowdfunding. Actually becoming partakers and authors of this project, together with me!

What I Need 

My budjet is 2500€ 

The Goal of 2500 € will allow me to carry out one or two installations, video material and photos. 

The expenses I will face are the following:

-Purchase of 5 or 6 metres of iron tube for each mannequin plus joints and pedestals (about 90-100 € per figure),.

-Transportation costs (about 150€);

-Costs of the lighting system for the installations (about 200€);

-Rent of a working space with suitable equipment for the assembling of the installations (approximately 500€);

-Purchase of additional materials to metal tubular skeletons (barbed wire, metal wire netting, fabrics, clothing, cables, plastic etc.), variable cost from € 200 to € 500;

-Costs of graphic works (flyers, prints for the installations, catalogue etc.) and video production 400€.

The real goal is this: more money we can collect and the work that I will to create will be more effective and complete.

I have fixed intermediate budgets. With 3500 € I will be able to make one of three installations in addition to the initial event. With 5000 € I will make the first part and two installations. As mentioned above, the budget that would allow me the complete realisation of the project is 7000€.

If I do not will reach the goal

If I do not will reach the goal of 2500 € the money collected will be used for the same project. More money will be collected by other benefactors. The progress of the project can be followed on facebook page.

Become a Patron of the Arts

Many centuries ago there were the patron of the arts but they were rich people. Today you can become one, without being rich! Support the arts and support the refugees! Your name and your face will appear throughout the life of these installations. Everyone will know who has contributed. If you participate in the crowdfunding you will become author with me of this work! 

Read perks and choose with how much money you want to participate!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not contribute with money, but want to participate in this project, share the link to your social! Talk about it to your friends and family.
story_txt:
Brief history of the project
My name is Pietro Fedele, 26, from Pescara, Italy. 
After attending the Art School, I got a degree in industrial design that allowed me to delve into modelling studies and a master's degree in multimedia design thanks to which I have been involved in the study of Exhibit Design. My studies led me to become a drawer, a multimedia and industrial designer, and they have done nothing but suggesting me the means to tell the stories that I deem are worth telling. Today’s story is on the refugees.
It is urgent to tell this story!
Nowadays we hear about them every day, everywhere, but the image that flashed continually in my head and asked to be expressed, was that of a mass of people without identity. They are just the refugees, the nameless, the rescued, the migrants, the invaders… and I said to myself: I must tell their story!
Interviews? Reportage? Photographs? None of that. What I wanted to realize was instead an itinerant art installation, in motion, as are refugees.
The subject I wanted to deal was that of identity and of political, social and geographical barriers.
The Art Installations
The first installation will be held in the streets of the city center, where small groups of mannequins without a body, but just "floating" clothes standing in significant poses will be exposed without specific description.
 «Who are they?» I hope, passers-by will wonder this when looking at these tragic and quiet figures that, perhaps only by their clothing, will recall the refugees.

I removed the vowels from the title, just as I removed the identity from the figures.
Subsequent installations  will take place inside the covered market of piazza Muzii in Pescara, at the charity event organized by AVSI. 


In the second installation figures "hanging from a fence with barbed" appear. They recall the anguished “climbings” on border barriers. When we see the pictures taken on site, these figures - that I will purposely call the hung - seem still, impotent, crucified, dramatic. A ragged semi-transparent tarp stands between the visitors and the work: another barrier, a translucent curtain full of meanings. 

In the third installation  a sole figure, there is a migrant with his hands tied behind his back. He is wearing a life belt which is, in turn, surrounded by a ring of barbed wire. His feet are in the Mediterranean Sea, represented on a map of Europe on the ground. The life belt gives only the illusion of saving but its tied arms, giving a sense of helplessness, the barbed wire and the geographic barriers are real constraints that make these crossings: “the crossings of death”.

In the fourth, a group of refugees is covered, harnessed, cold, seated, surrendered on a mattress, oars in hand, as if they were on a raft. Around them there are barbed barriers with slogans inciting to shutting and rejection.

The event in Pescara will just be the springboard for an exhibition that will travel to other cities, whose municipalities or non-profit and cultural associations will decide to host the installations and continue sharing with us the project.
WHY TAKING PART TO THE FUND RAISING 
I think making this project is worth especially for a reason: there is a need for awareness-raising and art is the best way to do that because a work of art never holds a single shareable or not shareable message, but opens to a deeper reading, raises questions, remains engraved in the mind, thus generating a reflection.
For this reason, I ask you to help me in carrying out this work by participating in the crowdfunding. Actually becoming partakers and authors of this project, together with me!
What I Need 
My budjet is 2500€ 
The Goal of 2500 € will allow me to carry out one or two installations, video material and photos. 
The expenses I will face are the following:
-Purchase of 5 or 6 metres of iron tube for each mannequin plus joints and pedestals (about 90-100 € per figure),.
-Transportation costs (about 150€);
-Costs of the lighting system for the installations (about 200€);
-Rent of a working space with suitable equipment for the assembling of the installations (approximately 500€);
-Purchase of additional materials to metal tubular skeletons (barbed wire, metal wire netting, fabrics, clothing, cables, plastic etc.), variable cost from € 200 to € 500;
-Costs of graphic works (flyers, prints for the installations, catalogue etc.) and video production 400€.
The real goal is this: more money we can collect and the work that I will to create will be more effective and complete.
I have fixed intermediate budgets. With 3500 € I will be able to make one of three installations in addition to the initial event. With 5000 € I will make the first part and two installations. As mentioned above, the budget that would allow me the complete realisation of the project is 7000€.
If I do not will reach the goal
If I do not will reach the goal of 2500 € the money collected will be used for the same project. More money will be collected by other benefactors. The progress of the project can be followed on facebook page.
Become a Patron of the Arts
Many centuries ago there were the patron of the arts but they were rich people. Today you can become one, without being rich! Support the arts and support the refugees! Your name and your face will appear throughout the life of these installations. Everyone will know who has contributed. If you participate in the crowdfunding you will become author with me of this work!

Other Ways You Can Help

story:
Hello.


My campaign funds will allow me to purchase the equipment and supplies needed to start a cottage studio where plastic bags are the main working material. Plastic bags and cotton twine.

We produce a LOT of TRASH and as an artist, making it into something else seems a good way to deal with it. Think about the glut of plastic bags you get with every purchase. I can weave those bags into sleeping mats or into artful wall hangings.

I can DONATE sleeping mats to my homeless neighbors and SELL artful wall hangings.

I know people crochet plastic bags into tote bags, but weaving is so much faster and mats are so much softer and water resistant, too! I also want to get away from wool because industrial sheep shearing is not a pretty thing.

The only cost is the tapestry/rug loom. (Leclerc Gobelin High-Warp Tapestry Loom) Which comes in at about $4500.00 (shipping and handling included. Shipping weight: 160 lbs (72 kg.)  For a 60” loom). The remaining $1500.00 will be for twine (the twine is the vertical thread while the bags, processed, become the horizontal thread) and accessories for the loom.

There are no risks. It's a one-time thing. When I raise the money, I'll make the mats and other things. What do you get out of all of this? Well, a sleeping mat, a rug or a waIl hanging.

PLEASE tell you friends about my idea ... as they say ... 'Get the word out!'

story:
My name is Andrea Rodríguez and I am a chilean artist, working with ceramics. Part of my work reflects my love and admiration for the animal world. With my sculptures and installations I’m constantly tackling the ever-fragile animal v/s human relationship, exploring concepts such animal threats, extinction, and domestication.

On the other hand, I’ve also been exploring the abstract world, giving to my artwork different visual possibilities, and therefore, different meanings.

As an artist, i'm interested in expressing mi concerns about the preservation of endangered chilean animals, exploring and tackling the complicated relationship between human beings, nature and the vast amount of species that constitute it: 

www.andrearodriguezvial.com

Why the Crowdfunding?

The reason why I’m doing this Crowdfunding is because I’ve been selected to do a 12 weeks, residency period at the European Ceramic Work Center (EKWC), in The Netherlands, from April 19th until July 11 2018.

In my country there are very few, if any, schools or workshops to deepen this technique. so i’m raising funds to cover the costs involved to be able to participate in this amazing place.

This center is known around the world as a center of excellence, because of its facilities and the best technical equipment. For me it will be an exceptional and unique opportunity to develop my artistic project and work on a completely different scale. I’ll be working 50 hours a week, being able to use all of its facilities, and learning from their highly qualified staff:

https://sundaymorning.ekwc.nl/en/over-ons/mission/

Well-known artists such as Tony Cragg, Akio Takamori and David Zink Yi have been also working in this center, giving to this place an unique and qualified status.

With your support I’ll be able to work in one of the best places in the world specialized in ceramics, which will help me to improve my professional development  and to promote, in an artistic way, my concerns regarding endangered species, a worldwide problem in which nowadays is important to care about.


The project:

The specific project regarding this Residency, consists out of continuing a project i started within I was working in Berlín and that concerns a specific endangered South American native animal called Pudú.

 

The Pudú is the world’ smallest deer, that habits in some South American countries like in Chile and Argentina. This animal is nowadays classified as endangered species, mainly because of overhunting and habitat loss. So their biggest threat for their proper conservation are men. In Chile, Pudús are protected in various national parks and zoos. Efforts to preserve the pudú species are being taken in order to prevent extinction.

While I was in Berlín i created a natural size Pudú, in clay, and then took the mold of it.

While i'm at EKWC i want to make the mold of each part of the mold of the Pudú ("The mold of the mold one could say") and then, reproduce in ceramic each part of the mold of the Pudú, for then be glazed and fired. I need to do work at this place because I'll learn and have all the equipment and facilities to do a good job.

The final work will consist out of an installation conformed by each part of the mold of the Pudú, made with ceramic and displayed in a way such, that the audience will be challenged, through the negative, to recognize each part of the figure. Like a puzzle that they have to reconstruct to obtain the main figure again. Concepts such as absence, memory, and frailty will be represented by this, alluding to what is not longer present (or will not be in the future if this species finally extinct)

As an example, here are some reproductions of molds made in ceramic and glazed with bronze pigment:

 

 For doing all this i need to raise USS 7.600 to pay for all the costs involved: living espenses, studio, facilities and materials.

Every contribution will help! Even if it is not a monetary one. You can also help by sharing this campaigne with other people!

This is the opportunity of my life!!! I'll have all the facilities to work with the best staff and equipments!

 

REWARDS!

30€

So nice for you to help me!

Supporters pledging $30 will receive a package of 3 postcards with some personal greeting words There are 3 different designs available! You can email me to see all the images

70€

This is getting better!

Supporters pledging $50 will receive A package of 3 postcards with some personal greeting words 3 miniatures of a handmade ceramic snail, with golden luster (8 x 8 cm. each one)

120€

You are a super supporter!

You have become a super supporter! Supporters pledging $100 will receive:

- A package of 3 postcards as a “thank you” greeting card

- A pack of 6 miniatures of handmade ceramic snails, with golden luster (8 x 8 cm. each one)

300€

The super super supporter!

Supporters pledging $200 or more will receive

- A package of 3 postcards as a “thank you” greeting card

- A pack of 6 miniatures of handmade ceramic snails, with gold luster

- 1 handmade ceramic miniature of a ceramic Pudú glazed in white, grey or black (20 x 15 cm approx).

This is an image of the pudú, before being glazed and finished:

€400

Better and better!

Rewards are getting better and better! This reward constist in:

- A postcard as a “thank you” greeting card

- A pack of 7 miniatures of handmade ceramic snails, with gold luster

- 1 handmade ceramic miniature of a ceramic Pudú (20 x 15 cm. aproxx) glazed in white, grey or black

- An exclusive handmade ceramic miniature, with golden luster.

Here some examples of the exclusive ceramic miniature 

€600

Thank you! Thank you!

- A postcards as a “thank you” greeting card

- a pack of 6 miniatures of handmade ceramic snails.

- one mini ceramic pudú (20 x 15 cm aproxx)

- 2 parts of the final artwork, which means 2 uniques ceramic reproduction parts of the pudú mold, with a special dedicatory. 

€700

Wonderful geometrical work!

This is a very special abstract art piece! - Supporters pledging $700 will receive this amazing ceramic geometrical art piece to hang on the wall (40 x 32 x 8 cm)

- a Pack of 9 handmade ceramic snails 

€900

So special supporter!

You are welcome to come a visit me into this amazing place! You will receive

- 1 postcard as a “thank you” greeting card

- 1 handmade ceramic miniature of a ceramic Pudú glazed in white, grey or black (20 x 15 cm. aproxx)

- 4 parts of the final artwork which means a ceramic reproduction of 4 parts of the pudú mold, with a special dedicatory.

€1000

One of the bests!

Do you like my ceramic pudú? Then one could be yours! And you are so special that you are welcome to visit mi into this amazing place and get to look to at all my artwork! Supporters pledging €1000 or more will receive: A  copy of the life size Pudú (69 x 31 x 34 cm.) glazed in white, black or grey, with a special dedicatory (only 3 available!)

story:
Hello World!

For those of you who don't know me, my name is Emily Dumas. I was born and raised in Vermont, and currently reside in Brooklyn, NY. I am an artist who uses creative outlets as mediums to best interact with the world around me. As I discover who I am and what I want to be in this life, it becomes plain to me that my truest happiness and sense of meaning comes when creating.

I plan to go on residency to realize a concept I have been developing for some time. As a young artist who is still unmasking the ways of a professional art career, this focused period of time is invaluable. Not only will I be in environments teeming with international artistic professionals, but the space is cultivated entirely for the discipline and focus required to produce art of meaning. 

I envision a large body of work that encompasses many mediums; all of the pieces tied by the motifs, topics and narrative surrounding:

Ancestral Inheritance, Elements of Self, Conception, Time 

All of this work culminating with an exhibition.

Prototypes and concepts for 'Arm Guys' textile sculptures 

The Plan

(December 1st- 25th) Art See Ocean Gallery is run by couple Theresa and Stefan Lekberg. Both are working artists, supporting themselves as well as the international artist community through their residency program in Sweden, just south of Stockholm. https://www.stefanlekberg.com/

(January 1st- 31st) Gæsteatelier Hollufgård is an art center in Odense, Denmark, offering education, workshops and housing to both Danish and international artists and community. http://gah.dk/?lang=e

I began research  and applications for residency programs in August this year. I have been open to all residencies and options, as some of the places I really wanted to go didn't fit in with the timing of my trip, although I got positive feedback from my applications. Each program asks for 'tuition' which covers the studios space & accommodation, food, the community and resources affixed with the art centers. 

Tuition Fees: $2,000

Travel: $1,000

.05% Indiegogo: $150

Any additional funding over my goal of $3000, will go towards materials, museum admissions in the cities I visit, the shipping costs associated with sending the installation from residency to residency and back to New York. 

Every single dollar will be acknowledged and appreciated! I will be keeping an online journal to share my process, experiments, thoughts and finished work with my supporters (you!). I've also thought up some fun gifts to send from along my journey, and some pieces of art in 'thanks.'

My last installation took about 2 months of production work, which is where I am basing my timeline and ideas of production for this body. Fellow artist Julie Kenniston and I completed Introspection in September of 2017. Our collaborative installation consisted of roughly 250 of my unique and hand soldered stained glass eyes, while Julie contributed her felted, printed and altered textiles to the 'nest.'

More about Introspection here https://edumas94.wixsite.com/emilydumas/projects

The Impact

Your support is simultaneously supporting international art institutions and all they stand for: International community, appreciation and validation of creativity, alternative entrepreneurship, global compassion, education and empathy.

I understand that not everyone can help with funding, but if you could spread the word and get others excited, that would mean so much! Art is important, and now more than ever; it is the key to our human experience and the history we leave behind.

My web page currently shows a brief selection of works in multiple mediums http://emilydumas.weebly.com/

story:
My vision for this project is rooted in two important thoughts, one being the exclusion that is felt by individuals outside of the art world, and two, the need for more diverse and non-commercially driven spaces for artists to explore experimental ideas and ways of creating. 

Open House would be unlike anything currently in existence in the Kansas City area, but drives inspiration from a similar project in Illinois called DEMO Project, an unused house slated for demolition but being temporarily used as a space for contemporary art. Artists are always in need of space to make work, but they also are in need of space that helps drive the nexus of the work. A home is a space that all humans have a direct connection and relationship to.

The house itself sits in a mixed-use neighborhood, with the google fiber enabled Homes for Hackers, Startup Village, a Barbershop, plus several other small businesses around single-family houses. The location offers a unique connection point for new collaborators and entry points to participating in the arts.

In addition to the neighborhood I have been in conversation with several organizations to collaborate with through the duration of this project: Imagine That!, Archive Collective, KCAI, G-CADD, and the Extraordinary Material Exchange.  

Project Instagram: @openhouse.kc

brandonforrestfrederick.com

Credits:

Logo design: J.C. Franco - http://www.jcfranco.com/

Videography: Jon Demonte - https://demontepictures.com/

Music: Claire Adams - http://claireadamsmusic.com/
story_txt: My vision for this project is rooted in two important thoughts, one being the exclusion that is felt by individuals outside of the art world, and two, the need for more diverse and non-commercially driven spaces for artists to explore experimental ideas and ways of creating. Open House would be unlike anything currently in existence in the Kansas City area, but drives inspiration from a similar project in Illinois called DEMO Project, an unused house slated for demolition but being temporarily used as a space for contemporary art. Artists are always in need of space to make work, but they also are in need of space that helps drive the nexus of the work. A home is a space that all humans have a direct connection and relationship to.The house itself sits in a mixed-use neighborhood, with the google fiber enabled Homes for Hackers, Startup Village, a Barbershop, plus several other small businesses around single-family houses. The location offers a unique connection point for new collaborators and entry points to participating in the arts.In addition to the neighborhood I have been in conversation with several organizations to collaborate with through the duration of this project: Imagine That!, Archive Collective, KCAI, G-CADD, and the Extraordinary Material Exchange.  Project Instagram: @openhouse.kcbrandonforrestfrederick.comCredits:Logo design: J.C. Franco - http://www.jcfranco.com/Videography: Jon Demonte - https://demontepictures.com/Music: Claire Adams - http://claireadamsmusic.com/

story:
My Story

Hey everyone! My name is Ashton and I’m currently an international undergraduate from Singapore studying at King’s College London for a Bachelor of Laws in Law. I come from a very small single-parent, low income family consisting of only me and my mom. My father decided to abandon us when I was 6 and has not been in contact since, leaving my mom to bring me up single-handedly.

The last year was extremely stressful for me as I was almost forced to drop out of school as I didn’t have enough money to continue pursuing my studies. Thankfully, I was fortunate enough to find a guarantor over the summer to guarantee a S$58,800 (approx. £32,987) loan. However, due to the nature of overseas education loans, the bank (CIMB Ltd) requires that I start repayment immediately following the disbursement of my loan – Yes, that means that I will have to start repaying S$637/mth (£378), in the midst of completing my studies, from December this year even without permanent income.

My loan tenure is for 10 years and I leave university in heavy debt for the next 7 years. Whilst I feel that it’s a small sacrifice to make for the opportunities I can potentially have, the circumstances of immediate repayment plunge me into a very untimely predicament where it is near impossible to keep up with payments.

I will need to use the remaining money that I have saved and worked for in London (and subsequent salary from a part-time job) for the repayment of the loan, leaving me with little or no money for rent and personal subsistence.

This is my plea to you for help with the first 3 years of repayment* as this will allow me to continue pursuing my studies stress-free until I am able to start practising as a trainee lawyer to pay the loan back by myself. It would be pretty amazing to be able to just focus on my studies, especially during my exam periods, instead of having to work part-time concurrently. Every pound you donate is a pound more for my next meal!

*The sum to be raised is calculated as such: £378/mth x 36 months + 5% Indiegogo Fees + 5% Paypal/Credit Card fees

The idea: Pokémon drawings 

Something I love doing is drawing Pokémon. I fell in love with Pokémon since the first Pokémon episode aired and since then started exploring drawing Pokémon. As such, I would like to appreciate and thank all donors with a drawing or quality photocopy drawing of a Pokémon.

My drawings are normally created using graphite pencils as the medium but I am happy to explore the option of coloured pencils upon request. I am self-taught and my drawings are usually done very carefully and precisely thus they can take a lot of time to complete. For example, the circle of Eevee-lutions took up to 15 hours! (See the gallery above)

If you feel that you would like one for yourself or as a gift for someone else, just take a look at the options at the side! Don’t worry, all photocopies of original drawings will be printed on quality matte photo paper. Please also provide an address and name for me to send the drawing to!

P.S. All drawings are made with love!

A Big Thank You!

A final thank you so much for reading this. I appreciate every donation, even if it is a just single pound! I understand that not everyone is able to contribute monetarily but if you can, please do help me in a non-monetary way by sharing this fundraiser so that I can reach out to more people; again, I appreciate and thank you all the same!

story:
Posters ship to USA, EU, UK and the rest of the world.

The Gravitational Waves Anniversary Poster

1.3 billion years ago - two black holes collided, releasing gravitational waves.

101 years ago - Albert Einstein published his General Theory of Relativity, predicting the existence of gravitational waves.

1 year ago - US-based LIGO detected the waves from this ancient collision and made the first ever confirmed recording of gravitational waves passing through Earth.

Today we celebrate.

Physics is more than numbers and equations. It is the best method we have to understand and connect with the beautiful universe we find ourselves in. Leaps forward in the subject, such as the detection of gravitational waves by the LIGO team, are incredibly exciting and deserve to be celebrated.

The Institute of Physics has teamed up with London-based entrepreneur Joshua Summers and Paris-based designer Louise Métvier to produce a commemorative poster to mark the first anniversary of this event. 

The poster will help raise funds for Physics for Development, a program run by the Institute of Physics, a London-based charity dedicated to ensuring that physics delivers on its exceptional potential to benefit society.

The Poster

The gravitational waves detected by LIGO were caused when two black holes spiralled into each other. As they drew closer together they orbited ever faster, and the strength of the gravitational waves they created increased, reaching its peak when the black holes collided and merged. The poster depicts these spiralling black holes and the waves they created.

The design was inspired by the imagery used by NASA on their official press release announcing the detection, seen below on the left.

The poster is available in four formats:

  • A digital download of the black & white image
  • A black & white print
  • A Tribute to the Collision of Black Holes black & black print
  • 100 posters signed by three members of the LIGO team

 

Different Perks to Purchase

To order on a desktop computer scroll to the top of the page and look right. 

To order on a mobile press the left pointing arrow (next to the word 'Story') at the top of the page.

Posters can be shipped globally. 

Shipping is free in the UK and £4 / $5 /  €4.6 to the USA and the remainder of the EU. We were not able to offer free shipping globally as the cost of getting the posters, when packed properly, overseas is too high. We have not passed on the full shipping costs to our international customers: to learn more please see the bottom of the page.

 

Digital Download (£5 / $6.25 / €6)

A high definition version of the image suitable for your smartphone or tablet background.

There are no shipping costs for this item.

 

Black & White Poster (£16 / $20 / €18.5)

Free Digital Download included

  • A2 / 42.0 x 59.4cm / 16.53 x 23.39 inches
  • 150gsm Claro Silk Forest Stewardship Council certified paper
  • Lithograph printed in London

The poster is printed with black ink on 150gsm Claro Silk Forest Stewardship Council certified paper. The lithographic printing technique involves injecting black ink into the paper, resulting in a poster with strong definition and an extremely dense black.

Staring at this poster gives you the feeling you are peering into the depths of deep space and experiencing the intensity of gravitational wave energy.

The poster comes with an A5 card explaining the significance and scientific method behind the discovery. A high quality digital version of the image suitable for your smartphone or tablet background is included free with this order.

 

Black & Black (£20 / $25 / €23)

A Tribute to the Collision of Black Holes

Free Digital Download included

  • A2 / 42.0 x 59.4cm / 16.53 x 23.39 inches
  • 170gsm black Forest Stewardship Council certified paper
  • Lithograph printed in London

The detection of gravitational waves was only possible due to the collision of two black holes. We wanted to pay tribute to their lack of light by offering a completely black version of the poster.

This effect was achieved using the lithographic printing technique where black ink is injected into high quality 170gsm black Forest Stewardship Council certified paper.

The difference between the texture of the printed areas and the unprinted areas of the paper means that the image changes according to the lighting in the room and the angle you view it from.

The poster comes with an A5 card explaining the significance and scientific method behind the discovery. A high quality digital version of the image (black and white) suitable for your smartphone or tablet background is included free with this order.

The Complete Set (£30 / $37.5 / €35)

Black & White and Black & Black

Free Digital Download included

Buy both posters at the reduced price of £30.

Each poster comes with an A5 card explaining the significance and scientific method behind the discovery. A high quality digital version of the image (black and white) suitable for your smartphone or tablet background is included free with this order.

100 copies signed by members of the LIGO team (£100 / $125 / €116)

Free Digital Download included

We have available 50 black & white and 50 black & black posters signed by members of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) team. They are James Hough OBE, Shelia Rowan MBE and Martin Hendry MBE.

To read an in-depth biography of James Hough please click here, for Shelia Rowan please click here, and for Martin Hendry please click here.

Each poster comes with an A5 card explaining the significance and scientific method behind the discovery. A high quality digital version of the image (black and white) suitable for your smartphone or tablet background is included free with this order.

More about the IOP's Physics for Development program

The Institute of Physics is a leading scientific membership society working to advance physics for the benefit of all. Its purpose is to gather, inspire, guide, represent and celebrate all who share a passion for physics. And, in our role as a charity, we’re here to ensure that physics delivers on its exceptional potential to benefit society.

A portion of the proceeds from poster and digital download sales will be used for the IOP’s Physics for Development program, which teaches scientists the key skills needed to transform their research into successful businesses.

The program consists of three-to-five day workshops where participants learn directly from highly experienced scientists-turned-entrepreneurs about writing business plans, scientific intellectual copyright laws and the requirements of business contracts.

Workshops have taken place, or are scheduled to take place, in Argentina, Brazil, China, England, Ethiopia, Ghana, India, Indonesia, Italy, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Mexico, the Philippines, South Africa and Tanzania.

Every country in the world produces excellent scientists who have the potential to be key engines for sustainable growth and positive change. The IOP's Physics for Development program increases the probability of this happening.

You can learn more about the Institute of Physics by visiting http://iop.org/.

The People Behind The Poster

Joshua Summers - Project Founder, London - https://twitter.com/joshsummersblog

Louise Métivier - Poster Design, Paris - http://louisemetivier.fr/

Charlie Brambridge & Harvir Gill - Movie Creation, London - http://www.willowcityproductions.com/

Sasha Hajnal-Corob - Physics Accuracy, Cambridge - http://www.damtp.cam.ac.uk/people/sjh245/

Risks & Challenges

We have reached the stage of getting the first batch of posters printed and we are very happy with the outcome.

There are risks involved with the distribution of the posters. The best practices will be followed with the posters being rolled into transportation tubes prior to distribution.

Currency translations from GBP to USD and EUR may differ from the amounts shown above. They were made using the standard Google converter and do not take into account any exchange rate fees. I am not aware of any exchange rate fees, but wanted to leave a note just in case.

International Shipping Rates

Please ignore this section if you are ordering to a UK address as shipping is free.

We are charging £4 / $5 /  €4.6 for USA and EU shipping. 

The cost of sending a poster to the EU is roughly £7.25 / $9 / €8.4 and the cost of sending a poster to the USA is roughly £8 / $10 / €9.3. We could not afford to cover the full cost and hope that splitting it 50/50 is ok with you.

We applied a blanket postal charge of £7 / $8.7 / €8.1 to the remaining countries. If you are not from the EU or US and believe you should have a cheaper shipping rate, please send me a tweet at @joshsummersblog.

story:
(per la versione del testo in italiano scorri verso il basso)

Art and Immigration

Contemporary art to talk about immigration, acceptance and awareness raising on an international issue that apart from the news goes on between silence and indifference  

Millions of people have crossed the sea seeking a better future.

Since 2013, more than thirty thousand people have died off the coast of Lampedusa, which is an island situated in the South of Sicily between Africa and Italy, that represent figures which deserves our daily questioning and reflection about women and children who have lost their lives at sea while attempting to cross The Mediterranean.

I am Domenico Pellegrino, a Sicilian artist, telling my art through my land. My lights are those that for centuries have adorned the cities of southern Italy during religious and patron saint festivals. My work is a tribute to my land and those rituals that mark the sacred and profane passing of the time which is proper of a folk sociality made of festivals, processions, baroque prospects, carousels, sequins, votive shrines, artistic lighting and shining altars.

When I create a work of art or I think of it, my attention is focused on traditions. The land where I live. I live in Sicily, in Palermo, which is a city that gives you a lot but at the same time requires a lot of you. I find inspiration in this city for everything I think and create, for my installations and my sculptures, which combine craftsmanship and tradition. That means I try to translate a traditional language in an international language.

 

Sicily, sea of light for Lampedusa

A Sicily rethought for Lampedusa, for its shape which resembles my own illuminated island, because going to Lampedusa, I made a reverse journey. I went through the route covered by travelers and immigrants of the sea. Migrants arriving from the sea look at the light of the Sicilian coast with hope, then the sea is for them a means of salvation but in the sea many people lose their lives.

 

I have thought of a light to reach, but also of a light that does not have a precise shape. It is a way of salvation in the darkness of navigation. I have imagined people who have not been able to get to this light, but who have brought this light with them. It is as if the last image impressed in the retina of the eye was the light of my land, the light of Sicily.

  

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

My Sicily is an act of love to the earth, to the sky, to the sea, to its people. In this context the work of art becomes a secret hidden from eyes embedded in the thought.

I imagined people who have not been able to get to this light, but who have brought this with them, a symbol with a strong emotional impact that mixes art and news.

 

Cosmogonia Mediterranea, we are all migrants

Mediterranean Cosmogony is the journey of the sea of light, as if the work of art was a traveler who takes energies from places and people encountered, acquiring knowledge and culture.

The energy from which it is contaminated allows it to be recharged to complete its journey to return to Lampedusa. The journey began in Lampedusa, in July 2016, in the depths of Cala Francese where has been settled the temporary installation which allowed the production of the video story #cosmogoniamediterranea.

Before returning to the waters of Lampedusa, the stages of its journey were the places of art, the spaces of life and artistic innovation.

  • Farm Cultural Park in Favara
  • Museum Riso in Palermo
  • Orestiadi Foundation in Gibellina
  • Loc in Capo d'Orlando

 With your support

With your support I will complete the final stage of this year, which concerns the carriage of  the island back to bottom of the Sea of  Lampedusa where it will stay for two months from 29 July to 30 September with the purpose to make it visible and visitable.  It will be settled in Cala Francese in a sandy bottom of the poseidonia. I'm organising a purifying bath that would like to see all the residents of the island involved, along with tourists and migrants in transit, temporary guests of the reception center.

 

I'm a lighthouse

At the end of  the exhibition, the same will be lifted from the bottom and permanently exposed in the harbor of Lampedusa, where the rescue boats dock.

Your donations will cover the expenses of this final part of my trip and if the planned budget  will be exceed then the funds will be used in the design and implementation of the next stages: Greece and Spain.

A complex operation that combines art and technology, led light, four meters of iron, full of small stars (lights) that bright under the sea.

I need your help to start this trip.

 

Perks

I would like to thank you by sending each of you a gift, a symbol, an object that also becomes a witness to my denunciation.

The phrases printed on the t-shirts refer to welcome, love, hope.

 

 

By adopting a light you will contribute to light my Sicily, sea of light, and you will receive a copy of the lamp with a hand-painted wooden base.

 

Limited edition

In my artistic journey, Sicily of lights born before my migrant journey and it is made of wood, with the technique of painting of the typical Sicilian cart, combining the technique of the lights used for the  of patron saint festivals.

This work is redesigned in limited edition, a Sicily for Lampedusa with a blue heart, available in two dimensions:

Width 150 cm

Width 200 cm

 

 

With Your Support

If I have the pleasure of receiving your support, I'll be able to create my artwork, fixed over then 400 light bulbs, come back in Lampedusa, create a workshop with immigrants live in the island, and donate my Sicily to all the immigrants who will come to Lampedusa.

Any donation, large or small, is greatly appreciated and considered important for keeping us active in making art, and sharing immigrants stories.

Cost Estimates:

  • Lights                              € 3.000,00
  • Production

(irons, cutting, finish)        € 5.500,00

  • Trasportation               € 2.500,00
  • Installation

(energy, boat, sub)             € 4.000,00

 

Remember that just sharing is important for us to reach more people.

 

And remember that just sharing is important for us to rich more people.

 

Testo in italiano

Arte e Immigrazione

L’arte contemporanea per parlare di immigrazione, accoglienza e sensibilizzare su una questione internazionale, che aldilà della cronaca passa sotto silenzi e indifferenza.

Milioni di persone hanno attraversato il mare sperando in un futuro migliore.

Dal 2013 più di tredicimila morti al largo di Lampedusa, isola a sud della Sicilia, tra l’Africa e l’Italia, numeri che devono interrogarci quotidianamente e farci riflettere, uomini, donne e bambini hanno perso la vita in mare nel tentativo di attraversare il Mediterraneo.

Io sono Domenico Pellegrino, artista siciliano, racconto la mia arte attraverso la mia terra.  Le mie luminarie sono quelle che da secoli adornano le città del Sud Italia, durante le feste religiose e patronali. Il mio lavoro è un omaggio alla mia terra e a quei riti che scandiscono il tempo sacro e profano di una socialità popolare, tra sagre, processioni, prospetti barocchi, giostre, lustrini, edicole votive, insegne strobo ed altarini accesi.

La mia attenzione quando produco o penso un’opera, parte da quella che è la tradizione. La terra in cui vivo. Io vivo in Sicilia, a Palermo una città che ti da molto, ma che allo stesso tempo ti chiede molto. In questa città prendo ispirazione per tutto quello che penso e produco, per le mie installazioni, per le mie sculture, che coniugano artigianato e tradizione. Cioè, cerco di rendere un linguaggio tradizionale in un linguaggio internazionale.

Una Sicilia, mare di luce per Lampedusa

La Sicilia, la cui forma richiama proprio la mia isola che si illumina, l’ho ripensata per Lampedusa perché andando a Lampedusa ho fatto un viaggio al contrario. Ho percorso la rotta che fanno i viaggiatori, ma anche gli immigrati dal mare. I migranti che arrivano dal mare vedono con speranza la luce della costa siciliana, il mare è per loro un mezzo di salvezza e nel mare molti perdono la vita.

Ho pensato a una luce da raggiungere, ma ad una luce che non ha una forma ben precisa. È una via di salvezza nel buio totale della navigazione. Ho come immaginato chi non è riuscito ad arrivare a questa luce, ma se l’è portata dietro. È come se fosse rimasta nella retina dell’occhio l’ultima immagine: la luce della mia terra, la luce della Sicilia.

La mia Sicilia è un atto d’amore alla terra, al cielo, al mare, alla sua gente. Immersa, l’opera diventa un segreto, celato agli occhi, incastonato nel pensiero.

Ho come immaginato chi non è riuscito ad arrivare a questa luce, ma se l’è portata dietro, un simbolo dal forte impatto emotivo che confonde l'arte e la cronaca.

Cosmogonia Mediterranea, siamo tutti migranti

CosmogoniaMediterranea è il viaggio dell’isola mare di luce, come se l’opera fosse un viaggiatore che si ricarica da luoghi, da persone che incontra, immagazzinando sapere e culture.
L’energia dalla quale viene contaminata le consente di ricaricarsi e di completare il suo viaggio ritornando a Lampedusa. Il viaggio è iniziato a Lampedusa, nel luglio 2016, nei fondali di Cala Francese è stata adagiata l’opera, questa installazione temporanea ha consentito la realizzazione del video-racconto dal titolo #cosmogoniamediterranea.

Le tappe del suo viaggio, prima di ritornare nelle acque di Lampedusa, sono stati i luoghi d’arte, gli spazi propulsori di vita e innovazione artistica.

  • Farm Cultural Park a Favara
  • Museo Riso a Palermo
  • Fondazione Orestiadi a Gibellina
  • Loc a Capo d’Orlando

Con il vostro aiuto

Con il vostro aiuto realizzerò l’ultima tappa di quest’anno, riportare l’isola sul fondo del mare di Lampedusa per due mesi dal 29 luglio al 30 settembre, renderla visibile e visitabile. Sarà sistemata a Cala Francese in un fondo sabbioso tra la poseidonia, sto organizzando un bagno purificatore che vorrebbe vedere coinvolti tutti i residenti dell’isola, insieme ai turisti e ai migranti in transito, ospiti temporanei del centro accoglienza.

I'm a lighthouse

Alla fine della sua esposizione sollevarla dal fondo ed esporla in modo permanente al porto di Lampedusa, nel punto dove attraccano le imbarcazioni dei soccorritori.

Le vostre donazioni serviranno a coprire le spese di questa parte finale del viaggio della mia Sicilia e se supereremo il budget i fondi saranno impiegati nella progettazione e realizzazione delle prossime tappe : Grecia e Spagna.

Si tratta di una operazione complessa che combina arte e tecnologia, luci a led, 4 metri di metallo zincato, piena di piccole luci (luminarie) che brillano sotto il mare.

Ho bisogno del tuo aiuto per proseguire il mio viaggio.

Ringraziamenti

Ho pensato di ringraziarvi inviando a ciascuno di voi un dono, un simbolo, un oggetto che diventa anch’esso testimone della mia denuncia.

Le frasi stampate nelle t-shirt gridano accoglienza, amore, speranza.

Adottando una lampadina contribuirete ad accendere la mia Sicilia, mare di luce e riceverete una copia della lampadina con una base in legno dipinta a mano.

Edizione limitata

Nel mio percorso artistico la Sicilia di luminarie è nata prima del mio viaggio migrante ed è realizzata in legno, con la tecnica della pittura del carretto siciliano unendo la tecnica delle luminarie delle feste patronali.

Questa opera viene ripensata in edizione limitata, una Sicilia per Lampedusa con il cuore blu, disponibile in due dimensioni:

larghezza 150 cm

larghezza 200 cm

 

Grazia al tuo supporto

Riuscirò a coprire i costi stimati per la realizzazione di questa ultima fase, a sistemare l'opera sotto l'acqua per due mesi e a donare l'opera all'isola di Lampedusa.

 

 

  • Luci                                 € 3.000,00
  • Produzione                  € 5.500,00
  • Trasporti                      € 2.500,00
  • Installazione               € 4.000,00
story_txt:
(per la versione del testo in italiano scorri verso il basso)Art and ImmigrationContemporary art to talk about immigration, acceptance and awareness raising on an international issue that apart from the news goes on between silence and indifference  Millions of people have crossed the sea seeking a better future.Since 2013, more than thirty thousand people have died off the coast of Lampedusa, which is an island situated in the South of Sicily between Africa and Italy, that represent figures which deserves our daily questioning and reflection about women and children who have lost their lives at sea while attempting to cross The Mediterranean.I am Domenico Pellegrino, a Sicilian artist, telling my art through my land. My lights are those that for centuries have adorned the cities of southern Italy during religious and patron saint festivals. My work is a tribute to my land and those rituals that mark the sacred and profane passing of the time which is proper of a folk sociality made of festivals, processions, baroque prospects, carousels, sequins, votive shrines, artistic lighting and shining altars.When I create a work of art or I think of it, my attention is focused on traditions. The land where I live. I live in Sicily, in Palermo, which is a city that gives you a lot but at the same time requires a lot of you. I find inspiration in this city for everything I think and create, for my installations and my sculptures, which combine craftsmanship and tradition. That means I try to translate a traditional language in an international language. Sicily, sea of light for LampedusaA Sicily rethought for Lampedusa, for its shape which resembles my own illuminated island, because going to Lampedusa, I made a reverse journey. I went through the route covered by travelers and immigrants of the sea. Migrants arriving from the sea look at the light of the Sicilian coast with hope, then the sea is for them a means of salvation but in the sea many people lose their lives.

 
I have thought of a light to reach, but also of a light that does not have a precise shape. It is a way of salvation in the darkness of navigation. I have imagined people who have not been able to get to this light, but who have brought this light with them. It is as if the last image impressed in the retina of the eye was the light of my land, the light of Sicily.           My Sicily is an act of love to the earth, to the sky, to the sea, to its people. In this context the work of art becomes a secret hidden from eyes embedded in the thought.I imagined people who have not been able to get to this light, but who have brought this with them, a symbol with a strong emotional impact that mixes art and news. Cosmogonia Mediterranea, we are all migrantsMediterranean Cosmogony is the journey of the sea of light, as if the work of art was a traveler who takes energies from places and people encountered, acquiring knowledge and culture.The energy from which it is contaminated allows it to be recharged to complete its journey to return to Lampedusa. The journey began in Lampedusa, in July 2016, in the depths of Cala Francese where has been settled the temporary installation which allowed the production of the video story #cosmogoniamediterranea.Before returning to the waters of Lampedusa, the stages of its journey were the places of art, the spaces of life and artistic innovation.
Farm Cultural Park in Favara
Museum Riso in Palermo
Orestiadi Foundation in Gibellina
Loc in Capo d'Orlando
 With your supportWith your support I will complete the final stage of this year, which concerns the carriage of  the island back to bottom of the Sea of  Lampedusa where it will stay for two months from 29 July to 30 September with the purpose to make it visible and visitable.  It will be settled in Cala Francese in a sandy bottom of the poseidonia. I'm organising a purifying bath that would like to see all the residents of the island involved, along with tourists and migrants in transit, temporary guests of the reception center. I'm a lighthouseAt the end of  the exhibition, the same will be lifted from the bottom and permanently exposed in the harbor of Lampedusa, where the rescue boats dock.Your donations will cover the expenses of this final part of my trip and if the planned budget  will be exceed then the funds will be used in the design and implementation of the next stages: Greece and Spain.A complex operation that combines art and technology, led light, four meters of iron, full of small stars (lights) that bright under the sea.I need your help to start this trip. PerksI would like to thank you by sending each of you a gift, a symbol, an object that also becomes a witness to my denunciation.The phrases printed on the t-shirts refer to welcome, love, hope.  By adopting a light you will contribute to light my Sicily, sea of light, and you will receive a copy of the lamp with a hand-painted wooden base. Limited editionIn my artistic journey, Sicily of lights born before my migrant journey and it is made of wood, with the technique of painting of the typical Sicilian cart, combining the technique of the lights used for the  of patron saint festivals.This work is redesigned in limited edition, a Sicily for Lampedusa with a blue heart, available in two dimensions:Width 150 cmWidth 200 cm  With Your SupportIf I have the pleasure of receiving your support, I'll be able to create my artwork, fixed over then 400 light bulbs, come back in Lampedusa, create a workshop with immigrants live in the island, and donate my Sicily to all the immigrants who will come to Lampedusa.Any donation, large or small, is greatly appreciated and considered important for keeping us active in making art, and sharing immigrants stories.Cost Estimates:
Lights                              € 3.000,00
Production
(irons, cutting, finish)        € 5.500,00
Trasportation               € 2.500,00
Installation
(energy, boat, sub)             € 4.000,00 Remember that just sharing is important for us to reach more people. And remember that just sharing is important for us to rich more people. Testo in italianoArte e ImmigrazioneL’arte contemporanea per parlare di immigrazione, accoglienza e sensibilizzare su una questione internazionale, che aldilà della cronaca passa sotto silenzi e indifferenza.Milioni di persone hanno attraversato il mare sperando in un futuro migliore.Dal 2013 più di tredicimila morti al largo di Lampedusa, isola a sud della Sicilia, tra l’Africa e l’Italia, numeri che devono interrogarci quotidianamente e farci riflettere, uomini, donne e bambini hanno perso la vita in mare nel tentativo di attraversare il Mediterraneo.Io sono Domenico Pellegrino, artista siciliano, racconto la mia arte attraverso la mia terra.  Le mie luminarie sono quelle che da secoli adornano le città del Sud Italia, durante le feste religiose e patronali. story:
Short Summary

  • I graduated from Cal Poly San Luis Obispo with a B. of Architecture in 2015 and will be starting my master's degree in architecture at the Harvard Graduate School of Design in the fall. My primary focus is on how architecture can encourage interaction between strangers in public spaces. I think as the digital age continues to consume us we are growing far less present in the physical realm, particularly in public urban spaces which are so vibrant filled with opportunity! I hope that through my work I can bring about a new wave of connectivity to dense urban areas.
  • Autumn Austin graduated recently from California College of the Arts with a degree in Interior Design. She too carries a deep interest in the public urban realm, and loves to make things. Our shared passion for fabrication, innovation and creation has lead to this incredible project. 
  • Devon Meyers is a light and installation artist located in San Jose, CA who has worked on lighting for many large Burning Man art projects including this year's Roshania. His light art has been featured at events such as the Art of Dying, SF Music Tech Summit and Art and VR. He is the head of lights for the annual GlowCon event in SF.
  • This is piece is an exploration of biological forms, and mimicking the diffraction of light through water. We are very passionate and believe this will elicit curiosity as well as give visitors a memorable experience. Having shared experiences and transformative opportunities with others in shared public spaces permeates a deep level of connection amongst the community and a strengthened individual understanding of the city.

What We Need & What You Get

  • To create the full-fledged vision of our piece we would like to use dichroic film, which is quite costly, but very powerful in creating multi-colored shadows, and very dynamic diffraction patterns which we are seeking.
  • We would also like to incorporate responsive sensors and components which would be run off of an Arduino to create a more intimate and personal experience for users.
  • The project has taken on quite a large scale, and we would love to carry out the concept to it's fullest, and let the project be what it wants to be! For that we will need a little support from our patrons!
  • We are so stoked to see it come to life, and cannot wait to share this piece with you June 1-3 at Lytton Plaza, Palo Alto.

The Impact

  • This project is pushing the boundaries of what can be created and the public impact it carries.
  • By sponsoring the arts and these prototyping festivals cities are making the first stab at reviving public space, and inviting the community out to experience and share these works with one another.
  • This initiative is a powerful platform to bring back public life and civic ownership to cities and the public urban realm.

Risks & Challenges

  • Time is running out so we are trying to make the final big push to finish our piece and convey the full concept to the public.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share our campaign and any amount helps! We have put so much into this project and hope it will be everything we'd hoped for the CODE:Art prototyping festival and for the city of Palo Alto!
story_txt:
Short Summary

I graduated from Cal Poly San Luis Obispo with a B. of Architecture in 2015 and will be starting my master's degree in architecture at the Harvard Graduate School of Design in the fall. My primary focus is on how architecture can encourage interaction between strangers in public spaces. I think as the digital age continues to consume us we are growing far less present in the physical realm, particularly in public urban spaces which are so vibrant filled with opportunity! I hope that through my work I can bring about a new wave of connectivity to dense urban areas.
Autumn Austin graduated recently from California College of the Arts with a degree in Interior Design. She too carries a deep interest in the public urban realm, and loves to make things. Our shared passion for fabrication, innovation and creation has lead to this incredible project. 
Devon Meyers is a light and installation artist located in San Jose, CA who has worked on lighting for many large Burning Man art projects including this year's Roshania. His light art has been featured at events such as the Art of Dying, SF Music Tech Summit and Art and VR. He is the head of lights for the annual GlowCon event in SF.
This is piece is an exploration of biological forms, and mimicking the diffraction of light through water. We are very passionate and believe this will elicit curiosity as well as give visitors a memorable experience. Having shared experiences and transformative opportunities with others in shared public spaces permeates a deep level of connection amongst the community and a strengthened individual understanding of the city.

What We Need & What You Get

To create the full-fledged vision of our piece we would like to use dichroic film, which is quite costly, but very powerful in creating multi-colored shadows, and very dynamic diffraction patterns which we are seeking.
We would also like to incorporate responsive sensors and components which would be run off of an Arduino to create a more intimate and personal experience for users.
The project has taken on quite a large scale, and we would love to carry out the concept to it's fullest, and let the project be what it wants to be! For that we will need a little support from our patrons!
We are so stoked to see it come to life, and cannot wait to share this piece with you June 1-3 at Lytton Plaza, Palo Alto.

The Impact

This project is pushing the boundaries of what can be created and the public impact it carries.
By sponsoring the arts and these prototyping festivals cities are making the first stab at reviving public space, and inviting the community out to experience and share these works with one another.
This initiative is a powerful platform to bring back public life and civic ownership to cities and the public urban realm.


Risks & Challenges
Time is running out so we are trying to make the final big push to finish our piece and convey the full concept to the public.

Other Ways You Can Help
Please share our campaign and any amount helps! We have put so much into this project and hope it will be everything we'd hoped for the CODE:Art prototyping festival and for the city of Palo Alto!

story:
The Meatstick

We've all said to ourselves at one point or another, "Dildos are great, but what could make them better?"  Well, this is a question that has echoed throughout the annals of time, but finally, after centuries of innovation, we have come up with the ultimate answer: Put donut shapes on the dildo!

Hi, I'm Brentcat.  I'm an artist and designer based out of Denver, Colorado, and I am so incredibly proud to introduce to you the pinnacle of my life work: The Meatstick!  

This has been a labor of love for me.  Years of extensive research and development have gone into this.  Designs were carefully worked over, each perfected to the most minute detail, and then discarded without a second thought.  Model after model was meticulously tested in laboratory environments, searching for that perfect combination of width and girth, and dildo and donut. Today, I am proud to share with you the fruits of my labor.

The Mona Lisa.  The Taj Mahal.  The Sistine Chapel.  The Meatstick.  It is such a great honor for me to be able to share with you my gift to the world.  Masterpieces come around once an era.  This is that masterpiece.

These are professionally made dildos, crafted out of high end medical silicone.  They are soft to the touch, and wobble in the breeze.  These are, quite literally, the finest dildo materials available.  You are paying for quality.  They are 7.9" by 1.4", and weigh about 3/4 of a pound.  They are sturdy, and could seriously injure someone if you were to smack them in the face with it.  They'll leave a hell of a mushroom stamp.  And, of course, they are decorated with a donut pattern, which has been dyed into the silicone.  These are FDA approved, and perfectly safe for human insertion.  These are a novelty item, but rest assured, they are quality dildos, meant to be used.
 

What We Need & What You Get

The first manufacturing order has already been placed.  But The Meatstick will sell out.  What we need is some cash flow to keep those dildos flopping in our happy customers hands, and have enough ready for Dicks in September! 

Risks & Challenges

The first order is already in production!  The second has already been placed!  The biggest issue will be communicating with the Chinese manufacturers, and keeping merchandise in stock.

Like life, nothing is perfect.  While we will try and get the pattern as close to perfect as possible, these are done by hand, in bulk.  Some variations will occur.

Other Ways You Can Help

This is some silly shit.  There's no denying that.  If it made you laugh, but you don't want to purchase the Meatstick, or any of the other penis inspired rewards, please just share this campaign!  Every share helps make the dream become a reality!
