story:
Short Summary

Immerse yourself into a world you might not have visited for some time – a colourful, mindful, deeply personal place where you can relax, find peace for a few moments from todays often busy life and discover extraordinary things about yourself.

Filled with a wide variety of pictures and exercises, The Big Mindful, Colourful Book is yours to complete at your leisure. Whether you want to zone out or focus inwards, explore or connect with yourself, this is your opportunity to be whisked away into a world of daydreams, doodles, drawings and the corners of imagination often unvisited.

This book brings Adult Colouring to another dimension and gives you the opportunity to share a deeply personal journey of self discovery and peace.

Why We Created It

Towards the end of 2014, my Mom had to have an operation. According to the doctors, things went well. They were wrong. On 24th November 2014, she was diagnosed with Stage 4 Lung Cancer - less than a week later, she was gone. 

As a recovering Addict and someone who deals with a few Mental Health Challenges, finding ways to deal with the situation were difficult but "doodling" came to the rescue. 

We've taken these doodles and turned them into something we believe is truly special and not just your ordinary, everyday adult colouring books.

This will be our way of paying tribute to a truly special lady. 

What We Need & What You Get

As a new and young business, we need to raise the funds to bring this to life. Whilst it is our dream to help as many people as possible, we know that to start off with, we need to be realistic and have decided for a first print run of either 500 or 1000 copies - obviously, the more we print, the lower our retail price can be.

As this is a bespoke project that needs to be put together on page at a time, start up costs for the first print run were higher than we had hoped.

We've taken the images we have created and turned them into 3 products that we would like to bring to life:-

1) The Big Mindful, Colourful Book - our Adult Colouring Book with a difference containing images and exercises for you to complete at your leisure.

What makes this part of the project the most exciting is that this promises to be a never-ending journey once you have purchased the book. At the back, we have details on how you will be able to get a new image every fortnight to download, print and colour at your leisure, as well as an opportunity for something else that is really exciting - an Adult Colouring Book where YOU get to be a contributor.
2) My Big Mindful, Colourful Year -  an interactive, living, "personal diary" and colouring book for the year that can be started at any time you choose.
3) The Colourful Life Cards - a deck of 64 cards to be used as a guide to uncovering your true potential.
This first round of Fund Raising will support us in bring Project 1 and 2 to life which will then, in turn, fund brining the third part of it all to life. We have already started production of The Big Mindful, Colourful Book and this should be ready for release in the next few weeks.

When you make a contribution towards this project today, you'll receive a "taster" booklet that we have put together containing 5 images (not included in The Big Mindful, Colourful Book) as well as 1 exercise to get you started.

The Impact

We (my sister and "brother") never expected things to go the way that they did and, in fact, I was planning to spend Christmas and New Year with my Mom and Sister in Zimbabwe anyway – something I had not done for many years since leaving the country in 2006. So as things progressed, and especially when they went down hill very fast, I needed a way to deal with everything that was going on and so began my collection of “doodles.”

The "doodles" were (and are) my continuing way of expressing and capturing feelings and emotions that I can’t put into words on paper. They were (and are) a symbol of things that my Mom loved and enjoyed in her life, but most of all, they are my journey and something that has helped me to find peace and calm during the most turbulent and challenging time of my life.

Over the last 8 months, I have spent time every single day “doodling” and it has now become time that I spend with myself. Time that I have to reflect on the day gone by, or the day ahead. Time that I have to allow myself to heal and find comfort during a personally painful time.

As someone who has always had problems switching off at night and sleeping (in the past, my addiction to drugs and alcohol dealt with that) I now find that this helps me to sleep better and be more productive and focused during the day. It has helped me think clearly and positively deal with my emotions and feelings. 

In 2014, we (my Business Partner and "brother") opened a Health Retreat in Spain - something we have worked our whole lives towards and sharing our experience with people has always been the most important thing that we do. Showing them the "doodles" have also brought them peace and understanding and thanks to them, we decided to bring this to life in our own special way.

In fact, just a few days ago we received an email from our Publisher who's Mother-In-Law passed away over the weekend before - this was what she had to say about the project: -

"I’ve still a few pages to proof read but done a good batch today, in between organising the funeral and all the other ‘stuff’ like cancelling hospital appointments for Mum etc. Grief is a really debilitating thing and reading your book I took strength from your experiences and your pictures took on a depth that I had not noticed before – they really are extraordinary you know?"

Risks & Challenges

I am not an artist neither do I consider myself to be artistically creative - in fact, I haven't drawn since I was a teenager at school and failed an art exam. Having done some research into the Adult Colouring Books currently on the market, I get somewhat overwhelmed by the beauty and creativity that is out there and yet, deep down, I know how much what has been put together has helped me. 


As someone who has always been committed to helping people, we felt that something could be added to what we do, so that people could get more out of the whole experience. 

If there is one important message that we like to share for people then it would be to face your fears and follow your dreams and this is our commitment to living the message that we share.

Who knows what will happen ? We can only find out with your help and support in bringing this all to life.

We know that what we have created is unlike any Adult Colouring Book currently on the market and this is what makes us a little bit excited about the whole project too.

Here is what our Proof Reader had to say about her experience with it all: -

"This doesn't often happen to me (as I'm sure you can imagine!) - I'm lost for words right now ... What an incredibly moving, powerful and extraordinarily magnificent thing you have created - I am just blown away, not just by the words, but also the exquisite 'doodles' I got so caught up in the journey of reading (and having hay fever eyes) that I lost my objectivity for proofing - you being able to bypass my 'red pen freakiness' is testament to JUST HOW GOOD THIS IS!

This is going to do the world so much good - and so far I've only seen half of it.  I've seen lots of colouring books, and that's just what they are 'colouring books' - yours is in a completely different league.  Can't wait to see it in print - and in use - everywhere!!! Thank you for the privilege of an early view."

Other Ways You Can Help

The BIGGEST THING YOU CAN DO to help us with this campaign, aside for making a contribution, is to SHARE, SHARE, SHARE and then SHARE some more. And please also feel free to share any ideas you have about spreading the message with us.

We would never be where we are today if it had not been for people supporting and encouraging us and this is the reason we choose to wear our hearts on our sleeves with everything we do.

What we have put together is deeply personal, sharing some of our most painful experiences with people in the hope that it will give them strength and peace of mind amidst challenging times. 

And if you know of any groups or institutions who would benefit from the use of our contribution to the world, we'd be more than happy to hear from you.

And that's all there is to it really.

story:
Who We Are 

The East London Stripper Collective (ELSC) have been given a great opportunity to hold a 10 day art exhibition, at the Red Gallery in London. This will be held at the end of October and we need your help.

The ELSC promotes the self-organisation of strippers in the UK, works to change negative societal attitudes to the industry and improve working conditions. The aim of this event is to counteract the stigma around striptease and celebrate the art of the dancers. 

We are a group of striptease dancers based in East London who have come together due to a shared grievance we have about the poor working conditions and exploitative business practises within our industry. We also lament the stigma surrounding our job; the lack of wider public understanding about what we do, compounded by negative connotations created by poor representations in mainstream media, combined with “feminist” campaigns that seek to erase our industry and destroy their livelihoods. 

In order to achieve this, we are planning an art event to celebrate the culture, art and aesthetic of our private universe. As multifaceted women, we are also visual artists and view what we do as an art from like any other, which takes time to develop, cultivate and practise. 

The event will take place over the course of ten days, combining an art exhibition, pole dance and movement workshops, a fashion show, life drawing, film screenings, an academic symposium, all culminating with a final closing party with live stage performances from the members of the collective. Hosted at the Red Gallery, Shoreditch, a mere stone’s throw from the longest running strip-pubs in Hackney.

The objective of the entire event is to celebrate, educate, and generally revel in a unique and endangered part of London’s culture – the strip pub. The ELSC wish to generate a culture of respect around their jobs, and to start by publicly recognising the value and worth of their creative energy. 

With your help, ‘The Art of Stripping’ will be a cultural milestone for London, enlightening the public with fresh insights into the intriguing hidden world of stripping and the women who dance. 

Here's our Manifesto and a short video about us.


Short Summary

The Art of Stripping event will feature:
Opening night - an exhibition of photography, installations, costume and film all created by ELSC members, as well as a lingerie label fashion show launch and an alternative cabaret.
Pole and Movement class - an opportunity for members of the public to come and train with the ELSC, learning pole moves and erotic routines. 
Stripper Wear Fair - a bring and buy sale (if you will), where we invite strippers from all over London to sell or swap costumes. The public in turn will be invited to come and pick up a bargain. 
Life Drawing - based on a regular, successful monthly event, where artists get to draw a strong, graceful pole dancer mid-routine. 
Academic Symposium - experts and academics from across the UK will present lectures and discuss 3 key topics; employment rights and licensing, migration versus repressive attitudes, and sexuality, bodies and performance. This will be one of the UK's very first academic event focused solely on stripping.
Film night - featuring films by dancers or about dancers, including Dear Delicious and Live Nude Girls Unite, with introductions from some of the film makers. 
Closing party - a Tarantino themed Halloween party, based on the film  From Dusk 'Til Dawn, featuring performances from members of the ELSC. 

What We Need & What You Get

The Red Gallery supports our aims so have given us the space for free, which is wonderful. However we need money up front for things such as; insurance, chair hire, covering the costs of security, cleaning and waste at the venue, printing, framing, paying the gallery technician and sound engineer. The costs of such an ambitious undertaking quickly mount up, as anyone who has produced an exhibition or event will know!
We hope certain events will pay for themselves in ticket sales - and in some cases ticket sales will subsidise free places to events - for example a proportion of seats at the academic symposium will be set aside to offer free student places. However it is the upfront costs of producing our exhibition and essential costs like insurance and technical support, that we need to cover in order to go ahead.  
You will get to support a ground breaking event whilst enjoying some amusingly titled perks! You can put a traditional pound in the tip jug if you want to keep it simple or be more extravagant with the VIP perks. 

The Impact

The Art of Stripping is shaping up to be a truly unique event, and we very much hope it inspires dancers in other places to get together and self-organise. As with many industries, workers have become more exploited and have less rights and representation. We'd love to cause a ripple effect. 
Empowerment is an overused word however this event 'empowers' in two ways. Firstly, it makes an impact by showing the other artistic skills of dancers, and how we combine them to create artistic narratives about our experience. A perfect example of this is the recent short film, Dear Delicious. 

Secondly, the ELSC have now run successful events for a year and a half and members have developed their business skills and become event producers in the process. We are building a very wide audience that is no way limited to the traditional 'male punter' as we have a huge age range and  gender diversity. 
As well as using art to challenge stigma and inform the debate, we are also politically engaged and have a wide understanding of feminist arguments, prohibitive legislation and good and bad business practises within the industry. Co-Founder Stacey Clare recently gave a TEDx talk covering these issues and the Art of Stripping event will add further to the wider conversation. 
§

Risks & Challenges

This is a big but exciting undertaking that challenges us all on a personal and professional level. The biggest risk we face is financial and we do not want to be left with debts at the end. Believe us when we tell you, stripping doesn't pay what it used to. Many of us are working full time to simply cover living costs, and are working every spare unpaid hour to make sure the East London Strippers Collective is a success. And while we can give freely of our time to a project we believe in, we simply do not have the capital to pay other people for their time and help. We want to be able to pay other people for their time and services, instead of relying on favours and freebies.
We have experience in producing one off events, and have been incredibly successful so far. This is the first time we have organised something quite so ambitious. Curating an exhibition, with an opening event including a fashion show and cabaret, dance workshops, costume fair, academic symposium, film screening and huge closing party - all within 2 weeks, is no easy task. However we have learnt a lot and feel really confident that what we are doing is tapping into a zeitgeist, that many, many people can relate and connect to, in one way or another.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help by sharing this campaign amongst your networks and spreading the word. If you want to put us in contact with press or anyone else you think could help, or if you are interested in the events, please contact us at ethicalstripper@gmail.com
story_txt:
Who We Are 
The East London Stripper Collective (ELSC) have been given a great opportunity to hold a 10 day art exhibition, at the Red Gallery in London. This will be held at the end of October and we need your help.

The
ELSC promotes the self-organisation of strippers in the UK, works to change
negative societal attitudes to the industry and improve working conditions. The aim of this event is to counteract the stigma around striptease and celebrate the art of the dancers. 
We are a group of striptease dancers based in East London who have come together due to a shared grievance we have about the poor working conditions and exploitative business practises within our industry. We also lament the stigma surrounding our job; the lack of wider public understanding about what we do, compounded by negative connotations created by poor representations in mainstream media, combined with “feminist” campaigns that seek to erase our industry and destroy their livelihoods. 
In order to achieve this, we are planning an art event to celebrate the culture, art and aesthetic of our private universe. As multifaceted women, we are also visual artists and view what we do as an art from like any other, which takes time to develop, cultivate and practise. 
The event will take place over the course of ten days, combining an art exhibition, pole dance and movement workshops, a fashion show, life drawing, film screenings, an academic symposium, all culminating with a final closing party with live stage performances from the members of the collective. story:
Background

(skip to Short Summary below if familiar with my work)

  • Flyers? Have done hundreds, and there's a small gallery of them under Graphics on my site. You've seen them all over town. Have designed all but two for Fleur de Tease since September 2008. Most of the NOLA Vintage & Lifestyle Expo posters. Half of the Slow Burn images, and about half of the Freaksheaux to Geaux flyers. Also have done flyers for Bella Blue, Storyville Rising, Dr. Sketchy's, Dance Quarter, NOLA Spaces, Les Rebelles, NOLitas, Sun Ray Grill, Aloha Sushi, Abby Travis, SWANS, and many other clients, with the entirety of design for the Snake Oil Festival, from stickers, to posters, shirts, to coffee mugs, even the video and original music. If you want something similar to what you've seen, I'm the guy for you.
  • Live Photos? Have shot hundreds of shows. Have shot every Fleur de Tease show since 2008. Have shot Brian Setzer, Swans, The Angels of Light, NOLA Bingo Show, Eagles of Death Metal, Gal Holiday, Debauche, Jarboe, Joseph Arthur, Outlaw Order, Rock City Morgue, Slick Idiot, Genitorturers, KMFDM, and the only American to ever shoot TATU. I have shot, easily, over 200 Burlesque shows, dozens of corporate events, conventions, even the occasional wedding. If you have decent light at the venue, see what I've done from my website, and contact me.
  • Boudoir? I have shot dozens, likely over one hundred, boudoir/fashion shoots for magazines, private contracts, promo, and independent art agreements. I am very adaptive, and to see what I do best, visit my website, and look under 'Models.'
  • Webisodes/Show Internet Packages? You can see my work in all of the 'CCN' news episodes of CouplesCruise's YouTube channel, all of the 'OpenLove101' video blogs on their YouTube Channel, as well as the latest two films under FILM on my website. I have some yet-to-be-released material in the works, as well as negotiating some actual commercials, and movie shorts. Obviously, this covers a lot of ground with only a handful of releases. Talk to me, and we'll see if this is right for you. The flyers and photos are better fleshed out in the details above.

Short Summary

  • I need some new equipment, and maintenance on existing equipment, my usual prices are technically too low, and every now and again I find myself in the situation I am in now. My fault. However, everyone I work with stands to benefit from this project.
  • Everything in this list is specially priced as a presale of services, but if you just want to donate, I won't stop you.
  • Some perks are priced more than usual, to make it worth the while minus physical expenses (printing, shipping, etc,) The bigger, more expensive ones are actually priced DOWN very significantly.
  • If the goal is not met, will still do what I can to get the lens at least, that way everyone benefits. I will simply purchase items in order of urgency.

What I Need

  • CanonEF 16-35mm f/2.8L II USM Lens.
  • New OEM Canon Batteries, and some upgraded studio accessories.
  • Tune up of the mechanical parts of my existing 7D.
  • New shotgun-style boom microphone ($250-$500 range.)
  • Slide mount for video, with motorized mount.

The Impact

  • Everyone contributing will benefit from the new equipment.
  • Some prices for some services are far less than my usual going rate.
  • Any overages of intended goal will simply go into more equipment!

Risks & Challenges

  • New Orleans happens. That is, income is a delicate thing here, and quite often there is a significant delay between services I provide and getting paid from personal clients, while always honored in the end, little to no budget can be had for such things in this common instance.
  • This is simply a pre-sale of services. You want me to do ____ within the next six months to a year? Now's a great time to confirm, and your project will be done with new and better equipment!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Have old Canon/Lighting equipment you want to donate? See if I can use it.
  • Can't use my services? Forward this to someone who does, and personally refer me as to your opinion. Though I am giving priority to those who actually know me and familiar with my work, if you know the 'right' person to see this, please forward it to them.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
• 15 Days
  • 1,500 Facebook Likes
  • $1,500 

Help us kick off the summer walking tour season by boosting our social media efforts and making a charitable donation to Historic Milwaukee, Inc.  Our goal is to add 1,500 Facebook "likes" to our page and raise $1,500 in donations in the next 15 days.

Did you know that Historic Milwaukee, Inc. is the only nonprofit provider of walking tours in Milwaukee? And that's not the only cool thing about us:

  • We offer a daily downtown tour at 10 a.m. Take an early lunch and join us starting Monday June 8th.
  • Our Sunday afternoon North Point Mansion tour is our most popular walking tour. Bring mom and grandma and have a great time.
  • We're kicking off a new Thursday night Riverwalk tour June 18th. 
  • Our tours are priced at $10 for adults and $2 for kids!

We need your help in the next 15 days!

Social media:

  • We want to have 10,000 Facebook "likes." We're about 1,500 shy of that number. Like us here and tell your friends to do the same. 
  •  Already a Facebook friend of HMI? No problem: we will be awarding two free memberships to anyone who has or will like our page by June 15th.
Donations:
  • Make a gift to help us raise $1,500 and get FREE walking tour passes and other great perks.
  • All donations will be used to support the educational programs of Historic Milwaukee, Inc. including the FREE Doors Open celebration set for Sept. 19-20.

story:
Our Project 

The Bangladeshi American Creative Collective (BACC) is proud to present Transitions: A Photography Exhibition, on view at the Bronx Museum of the Arts from October 15, 2015 to February 14, 2016. 

[Image above: The Lovers Redux by Manir Mrittik]

We teeter on moments of change, brought by forces that reach in and push out. Memories checker our thoughts; we wonder what decisions will be carved into the borders that frame our histories, and futures. What hangs in the balance, what will reach its limit, and where? And afterwards, what tokens will we be left with: a hesitant embrace, a scar, a burst of light? Our stories weave in and out of these visions.

With the rise of factories, investors, and development, the landscape of Bangladesh is changing. The spotlight has been turned on, and the people are trying to figure out what it means for them. This exhibition will feature nine Bangladeshi photographers whose work reflects a diverse group of people, shifting economies, and changing lands. Its aim is to not only to collect and exhibit photography as art; but also as ideas about the country of Bangladesh. 

These photos navigate the stories of its people, landscapes, and its position in the world. Most importantly, the works provide viewers with perspectives of artists that are connected to the places they are capturing. We are proud to be collaborating with a cultural institution that is exploring the documentation of its own changing home, the borough of the Bronx, which is home to a growing generation of new Bangladeshi Americans. We hope to open important discussions around the meaning of changes, shifts, and transitions across generations and communities.

from Love Studio by Samsul Alam Helal 

What We Need 

The exhibition and all related Bronx Museum events will be free and open to the public. We still, however, need to raise at least $5,000 by September. This will cover the cost of 50-75 large high-quality prints and frames; shipping; promotional posters and flyers; consulting fees; and refreshments, travel costs, chair rentals, and projection and audio equipment for events. We want to engage as many people as we can from within the community and beyond, and make them feel included in a museum space. Even the smallest amount helps. Please give today.


from Close Distance by Jannatul Mawa 


"When people think about Bangladesh, they think about all the things they are going to give, but when they get there, they realize there is so much for them to take, and they should take as much as they can--culture, art, knowledge, wisdom, lifestyle--because Bangladesh has so much to give." 

- Shajia Rahman, founder of the Parkchester Bangla School


from Born in Slum by Saikat Mojumder

The Impact 


Transitions hopes to represent and reach a community that is largely glossed over and stereotyped in mainstream media. As Bangladeshi Americans who grew up in the US, we observe a stark asymmetry in the relations of our two homelands. Bangladesh provides the US with a significant portion of its readymade garments, yet among Americans, it remains one of the least understood countries in South Asia. Despite the increasing number of Bangladeshis in all five boroughs, especially in neighborhoods of the Bronx, they are sorely underrepresented. As quoted in Art Info and the New York Times, global interest in Bangladeshi art is growing, yet we want to add more to the conversation.

This exhibition takes off from the vibrant energy of Eyes On Bangladesh (Queens, NY, March 26-30, 2014), which featured the work of nine prominent Bengali photographers, including World Press Photo winner Taslima Akhter.

                                " I don't want to be an icon of poverty

                                          or a sponge for your guilt.

                                    My identity is for me to build,

                                               In my own Image."

                       - Shahidul Alam, founder of Drik Picture Library

Transitions will provide Bangladeshis with greater exposure in, and access to, New York's cultural & artistic landscape, and provide a way for all generations to recognize the diversity of their roots through the lens of the photographers. This in turn will open space for new inter-/intra-generational conversation, and perhaps even inspire the creation of new art.


from Death of a Thousand Dreams Taslima Akhter

The Team

Ayesha Akhtar, Director; Curator
Nadia Ahmad, Programs & Development
Bashma Sheea, Communications & Marketing
Mahfuzul Islam, Outreach & Programs
Nabil Rahman, Creative Advisor; Curator
Ayesha Sultana, Creative Advisor; Curator                                                                  
Shawn Choudhury, Fundraising Consultant 

Risks & Challenges

We are aware of long-held stereotypes about the art world: its reputation for attracting only certain demographics, or only those well-versed in art. We wish to combat these conceptions. Transitions is not a typical, largely hands-off exhibition; it is a show designed to create dialogue in the community through primary source materials. This is why your contributions are so needed, and so appreciated.

Other Ways You Can Help 

It is essential to raise the money as fast as we can, so that we can begin covering costs as soon as the pre-installation process begins. So please help by spreading the word. We will also need volunteers for the show, so just keep a look out for calls on social media! 


Join the Community

Keep in touch! By liking us on Facebook and following on Twitter, you make us stronger! Whether you talk, tweet, or blog, you can help us by getting out the word. Each time someone who believes in our mission shares our campaign, we will be one step closer to meeting our goal.
Tell a friend or five.

See you at the exhibition!
The BACC Team

Transitions hopes to represent and reach a community that is largely glossed over and stereotyped in mainstream media. As Bangladeshi Americans who grew up in the US, we observe a stark asymmetry in the relations of our two homelands. Bangladesh provides the US with a significant portion of its readymade garments, yet among Americans, it remains one of the least understood countries in South Asia. Despite the increasing number of Bangladeshis in all five boroughs, especially in neighborhoods of the Bronx, they are sorely underrepresented. As quoted in Art Info and the New York Times, global interest in Bangladeshi art is growing, yet we want to add more to the conversation.
This exhibition takes off from the vibrant energy of Eyes On Bangladesh (Queens, NY, March 26-30, 2014), which featured the work of nine prominent Bengali photographers, including World Press Photo winner Taslima Akhter.
                                " I don't want to be an icon of poverty
                                          or a sponge for your guilt.
                                    My identity is for me to build,
                                               In my own Image."
                       - Shahidul Alam, founder of Drik Picture Library


Transitions will provide Bangladeshis with greater exposure in, and access to, New York's cultural & artistic landscape, and provide a way for all generations to recognize the diversity of their roots through the lens of the photographers. This in turn will open space for new inter-/intra-generational conversation, and perhaps even inspire the creation of new art.
  


from Death of a Thousand Dreams Taslima Akhter
The Team
Ayesha Akhtar, Director; CuratorNadia Ahmad, Programs & DevelopmentBashma Sheea, Communications & MarketingMahfuzul Islam, Outreach & ProgramsNabil Rahman, Creative Advisor; CuratorAyesha Sultana, Creative Advisor; Curator                                                                   Shawn Choudhury, Fundraising Consultant 
  Risks & Challenges We are aware of long-held stereotypes about the art world: its reputation for attracting only certain demographics, or only those well-versed in art. We wish to combat these conceptions. Transitions is not a typical, largely hands-off exhibition; it is a show designed to create dialogue in the community through primary source materials. This is why your contributions are so needed, and so appreciated.

Other Ways You Can Help  It is essential to raise the money as fast as we can, so that we can begin covering costs as soon as the pre-installation process begins. So please help by spreading the word. We will also need volunteers for the show, so just keep a look out for calls on social media! 

Join the CommunityKeep in touch! By liking us on Facebook and following on Twitter, you make us stronger! Whether you talk, tweet, or blog, you can help us by getting out the word. Each time someone who believes in our mission shares our campaign, we will be one step closer to meeting our goal.
Tell a friend or five. See you at the exhibition!The BACC Team

story:
Hello folks.  I'm Carson Barnes.  I make beauty.


The short version first:

Original printmaking in modern media, the images of statues from the past brought to life again.  I marvel that nobody else seems to have conceived of this - it's a simple, simple idea but then it's all in the execution of the work, from the sculpture chosen as model, to the photograph of it, to the printmaking skill and the gleeful, wild joy of creation that makes her live again.

Who's this artist and what happened?

I've been making original art prints since the early 1970s and good at it since the early 80s (nobody needs to see my middle school or high school work!). I've shown up and down the west coast and at a few exhibitions as far apart as the University of Florida, Gainesville and the University of Hawaii, Hilo, mostly from about 1985 through 1998 and won a few prizes.  Seventeen years ago I injured both wrists in a bicycling mishap and finally - finally! - in the past couple of years technology has caught up such that I can print again.  Where I once used silkscreens to print in fine detail now I'm using a large format Epson printer and a Mac to make prints ranging from 8 x 10 inches to 27 x 39 inches.  They're originals, not reproductions, and the editions are limited to 50.  The way you limit a digital edition is delete the file once number 50 is printed, that's it, no turning back.

Making art has been crucial to my life, and having had to stop printing for these years (I kept going until the injury's effects progressed to stage I/II osteoarthritis) didn't mean I stopped seeing.  I stored up ideas and energy to make them happen.

I had been blessed in the 1980s and 1990s with a series of women willing to model for the photographs from which I made silkscreen prints, combining various or many images in each piece (that older work can be seen at the website, URL below).  Last year, after moving to the South from California, I found that there are marble statues in cemeteries, mostly from the early 1800s to mid 1900s with a few earlier, some more recent.  Many are generic, no particular person (a slim body of literature on burial customs and funereal statuary, much of it in French, goes into why that was), but some are emotional, thoughtful, expressive women of their times.  Many are beautiful in a way we'd recognize early in the 21st century, while others don't match well the current ideals of beauty.  My task has become to inquire of the image who these women were, how they felt, and present them and their emotions so that we the living can recognize those feelings, those gazes across time, and find our own feelings echoing a response.  You've met some who resemble them in appearance, in feeling.

The curator in charge at the Palace of the Legion of Honor in San Francisco (it's an art museum) once told me, "There's nothing new under the sun."  In my mid 20s that was a challenge, in my late 50s it's permission to use the past five centuries of art and thinking about it to make these beautiful prints.

A note on the video

Originally the video had my voice narrating that there are 60 images showing something of the states this piece went through to completion, that each state had sometimes dozens of exacting changes, and that this piece was wrought over the course of two months.  That version of the video is to be seen at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qMvk0aqfMRc .  After a couple of days it dawned on me that I'd  seen this cellist and a beautiful voice perform a song that would work better with the images.  So, that song is on the video and the explanation is here.  Thank you Sam and Robin.  Their music ( as Loop!Station) is on iTunes.

Why Italy?

I reached a turning point with a piece titled "Ice Queen" - the subject may have been a great friend and loyal to her family, her close confidantes, and on the other hand that same camaraderie and loyalty may not have been let shine on persons outside her acquaintance.  The statue was sculpted in the mid 2000s, and on investigation I found the face is indeed the face of the deceased - at that time, last year, there were still photographs of her on the internet - but the rest of the statue was copied from one sculpted in the 1880s and is in the Staglieno monumental cemetery in Genoa, Italy.  Oh!

I realized that it would be a very good idea to get to Genoa for a week to take hundreds of photographs.  I've found since the days of using film (I started making photographs in 1974 as an undergraduate) that one or two of every thirty images really capture what I need.  Cloudy days are best for photographing marble....

The piece in the video took two months to complete, a few have taken less time and one or two took longer.  This journey will end up producing two dozen or so new works which will take over a year to complete.  I am of course courting  galleries in Asheville, NC, Charleston SC, and Atlanta where this work could be shown to the broader public.  It's not avant garde, though the past five centuries of composition, use of light and shadow, and continuity of emotional realities in each person's life are of no time, and all times; composition, form, gesture, sfumato, geometry, color and light all have their parts to play.

Cost breakdown

While my daily living expenses are pretty well taken care of, they don't include this journey nor the amount of ink and paper that will be required to make the prints.  Ink cartridges are $125 each, there are seven of them at a time, and with test printing various portions of each piece, I'll run through about $3,600 of ink; paper made to last five centuries costs $7 per sheet and if this succeeds and my funders want prints as I expect, I'll be paying $250 to $300 for paper.  Airfare runs about $900 to $1000 roundtrip, a room to stay in via airbnb costs as little as $50 a night, meals I'm hoping to do for less than $50 a day.  So travel would cost about $1700, the remainder of the objective is paper and ink and the fees Indiegogo will deduct.  If the objective is more than met, I'll have more prints to make and deliver. 

I propose that funders may elect to have a print of those seen at carsonbarnesart.com or the one in the video, or they may wait for the new work, or see perks; all the perks are shown on the gallery tab here, it's up to the reader to match up the perk title with the gallery piece's title (or inquire, I'd be happy to make it more clear).  I found out today that on the iPhone at least one cannot view the gallery, those viewers will have to either look at the website or get themselves to a real computer.  I'm sorry, IndieGoGo has a lot of good points but I think their app has a couple of faults yet  All prints are signed, titled, dated and numbered.  Of course, anyone who wishes to contribute but does not wish to own print(s) may do so. These ARE made to be seen and to give pleasure.

If I don't reach the goal, well, I'll try a test run to Pere la Chaise cemetery in Paris, and use what is contributed for materials to satisfy requests for prints.  If it goes way over, I'll also visit Staglieno in Genoa and try to get to Vienna as well. 

Thank you

Never having done a crowdfund before, I hope I'll be able to notify all my Facebook friends, and that they or you will notify theirs in turn.  This work is beautiful.  Thank you for your support.

story:
(English follows)

La Semaine des Arts NDG

Du 24 au 30 août 2015, La Semaine des Arts NDG est un festival d'art et de culture organisé par les résidents de Notre-Dame-de-Grâce et pour tous! Tout au long de la semaine, les gens de tous les âges auront la chance de participer à une variété d'activités, y compris des animations pour enfants, des spectacles de musique, de la danse, de la poésie, de la nourriture offert part les cafés et restaurants, et des films dans le parc à la belle étoile!

Pour voir toute la programmation pour 2015, visitez : www.artsndg.ca

Ce festival entièrement gratuit est mis sur pied par un groupe de bénévoles dévoués, des artistes, collaborateurs et propriétaires de petites entreprises à NDG. Nous avons besoin de votre aide pour assurer la pérennité du festival ainsi que la gratuité des événements pour tous les participants.

Votre appui à un grand impact! Vos dons contribueront à payer :

- Les coûts de programmation
- Les salles de spectacles
- La promotion ( programmes , affiches , site internet, etc.)
- Les honoraires pour les artistes

Aidez-nous à financer cette 6e édition de La Semaine des arts NDG ! N'importe quel montant est apprécié! Si vous n'êtes pas en mesure de donner de l'argent mais vous souhaitez donner de votre temps pendant le festival, vous pouvez écrire à katrina@artsndg.ca

Merci !

Ambassadrice du festival/Festival Ambassador 
Kathleen Weil, Députée de Notre-Dame-de-Grâce et Ministre de l’Immigration, de la Diversité et de l’Inclusion


NDG Arts Week

From August 24th to August 30th 2015, NDG Arts Week is an art and culture festival organized by the residents of Notre-Dame-de-Grâce for all to enjoy! Throughout the week, individuals of all ages will have the chance to participate in a variety of activities including children activities, musical performances, dancing, poetry, food from neighborhood’s cafés and restaurants, and movies in the park!

For the complete schedule, please go to: www.artsndg.ca

This free week-long festival is put on by a dedicated group of volunteers, artists, collaborators, and small business owners in NDG. We need your help to make this outdoor event the best one yet while keeping the festival free for attendees.

Your support has a tremendous impact. We need your donations for:

- Programming costs 
- Venues 
- Promotion (programs, posters, website, etc.) 
- Artist Honoraria

Help us make this year's edition of NDG Arts Week festival the best one yet! Any amount is appreciated! If you are not in a position to give money but would like to give some of your time during the festival, you can write to katrina@artsndg.ca.

Thank you!

story:
The main goal of this project is promoting and supporting art, culture, artists and the beauty itself. It includes several art domains as music, theatre, plastic arts and dance. Seven artists are implied in this project: 4 musicians, an actor, a painter and a dancer.

The event will take place in the downtown area, next to the main and most crowded station, in a rush-hour (The bus station next to McDonald’s, center of Chisinau, a working day, between 5 and 7 o’clock p.m.). The event will not last for more than 40 minutes, being a mixture of an ordinary concert and a flash mob.

The artists will present at once art – pieces from the classical period of their own art – domain:

- The 4 musicians will perform a piece of classical music;

- The actor will recite several poems and quotes from the classical theatre period;

- The painter will reproduce a classical masterpiece;

- The dancer will present a piece of classical dance- ballet.

Other 2 persons will be sharing leaflets to people going by. The information included there is about:

-  The benefits people gain from art ( based on scientific reports);

-  The most important cultural events that will take place the following week (month);

-  Some general information about all places of cultural interest from Chisinau (concert halls, theatres, galleries, museums, etc).

In addition, a professional photographer and a professional camera operator will record the whole event.

In order to be well organized, the project also needs a web-designer, an accountant, a sound director, and an introducer. Also there is the initiative group, formed by 3 people (the authors of the idea and of the concept). There are 18 people implied per total.


                                                            ART! Why?

Education and art are subjects our society is constantly interested in. Most of the developed countries appreciate and promote art in its various forms, from singular events to big festivals. Although the ticket prices are high, the concert halls of the modern cities are always full. It proves a high interest in art. This countries have to serve as an example for the Republic of Moldova, where art is still disconsidered.

Moldova suffers a deep motivational crisis. If we want to change this aspect, we need to change the way people think. For this reason, we need to support, invest and develop education and culture! This project is innovative for Moldovan society.

 Another problem is the fact that many open-minded and young people do not visit very often the cultural institutions of our city. So, the audience is limited and the development and maintenance of the concert halls is put at risk.

As a consequence of this project, we will see how youngsters become more interested in diversing their social and civic life through art. Many children will discover a predilection for practicing and discovering themselves in culture.

The importance of art will be perceived more deeply by humans. The stereotype of considering art only a hobby will be eliminated and art will be understood as a destiny.


                                                              Who wins?!

This project has no age/gender limitations. Initiated or not in art, everyone will benefit from this project:

- Civil society;

- People who will simply pass by;

- People who will get in/out of the public transport in the bus station;

- Students and pupils who study in the educational institutions next to the bus station;

- People who will learn about the event;

Per total, around 3000 people.


                                                  What do we want to do?!

1.  To promote music, theatre, plastic arts and dance.

2.  To promote our artists.

3.  To create a connection between the artists.

4.  To let the society know about the scientific reports on the benefits of art for the human body.

5.  To inform the society about the cultural events which will take place the following week (month).

6.  To inform people about the cultural institutions we have in Chisinau.

7.  To promote all cultural institutions of Chisinau.

8.  To prove that art connects people of different religions, ethnic groups – people of different social statuses, religions, ethnic groups are implied in this project.

9.  To promote the young generation – people aged 18 to 35 y. old are implied in our project.

10.  To enlighten the society and increase the level and quality of people’s socio – cultural lives.

11.  To promote active and non – formal education quality.

12.  To sensitize the society on the matters of culture.

13.  To find a solution for some of the existing problems of our cultural life, unsolved by the government (or the system), using a new and innovative method.


                                                     Future prospects!

We are enthusiastic and ambitious when speaking about letting art become a part of people’s lives. We want to increase the interest in art, to promote culture, because you cannot like what you don’t know.

This project exists because of our desire to develop it, because we want it to be a long – term one. The most important aims of the project are:

-  To create a Cultural Civic Association;

-  To organize more cultural events in different locations;

-  To extend the project on a wider range, in more cities and villages of Moldova;

-  To collaborate with international artists (from Romania, Ukraine, etc);

-  To motivate students and pupils from all artistic – profiled schools of Moldova to  become a part of our project;

-  To create connections between the main domains of art.


This project exists because of you! We thank you in advance!

Faithfully yours,

The representative of the initiative group,

Nicolae Leontiev.

Per total, around 3000 people.                                                  What do we want to do?!1. 
To
promote music, theatre, plastic arts and dance.
2. 
To
promote our artists.
3. 
To
create a connection between the artists.
4. 
To
let the society know about the scientific reports on the benefits of art for
the human body.
5. 
To
inform the society about the cultural events which will take place the
following week (month).
6. 
To
inform people about the cultural institutions we have in Chisinau.
7. 
To
promote all cultural institutions of Chisinau.
8. 
To
prove that art connects people of different religions, ethnic groups – people
of different social statuses, religions, ethnic groups are implied in this
project.
9. 
To
promote the young generation – people aged 18 to 35 y. old are implied in our
project.
10. 
To
enlighten the society and increase the level and quality of people’s socio – cultural
lives.
11. 
To
promote active and non – formal education quality.
12. 
To
sensitize the society on the matters of culture.
13. 
To
find a solution for some of the existing problems of our cultural life,
unsolved by the government (or the system), using a new and innovative method.                                                     Future prospects!We are
enthusiastic and ambitious when speaking about letting art become a part of
people’s lives. We want to increase the interest in art, to promote culture,
because you cannot like what you don’t know.
This project
exists because of our desire to develop it, because we want it to be a long – term
one. The most important aims of the project are:
- 
To
create a Cultural Civic Association;
- 
To
organize more cultural events in different locations;
- 
To
extend the project on a wider range, in more cities and villages of Moldova;
- 
To
collaborate with international artists (from Romania, Ukraine, etc);
- 
To
motivate students and pupils from all artistic – profiled schools of Moldova to
 become a part of our project;
- 
To
create connections between the main domains of art.This project exists because of you! We thank you in
advance!
Faithfully yours,
The representative of the initiative
group,
Nicolae Leontiev.

story:
What's going on?

  • YOUR Winnipeg Poetry Slam Team 2015 has agreed, this must be the single greatest road trip in the history of Winnipeg poetry and you can help make that possible! The team needs to raise funds for van rental, gas and hotel accommodation and food and that’s where you come in! By supporting our efforts to create the greatest road trip ever, you’ll help us rep Winnipeg at the Canadian Festival of Spoken Word in Saskatoon and you’ll gain access to some incredible perks, many of which are road trip themed!

  • The Canadian Festival of Spoken Word (CFSW) is the national level tournament for slam poetry where the teams from local scenes across Canada compete in a tournament to declare one team Canadian champions!

  • This year CFSW will take place from October 18th-24th in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. 

  • http://cfsw.ca/

What We Need & What You Get

We're asking for 3000$ to cover the cost of renting a vehicle, 6 nights of hotel stay for the team in Saskatoon, gas and food. We've already raised a good chunk (over 1000$) ourselves and will keep hustling, but we're aiming high in hopes that our community and those who support our art will help us get where we need to be. We're a team of artists and students and your help is what will allow us to take part in this grand adventure!

  • Check out our perks section! They're neat, unique, and they'll let you be part of this trip in real time!

Other Ways You Can Help

Keep an eye on our Facebook page and listen for our fundraising events! We'll be showcasing and workshopping and you'll be invited to come take part, to come see what it is we do!

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winnipeg-Poetry-Slam-at-CFSW-2015/739707096151084?fref=nf

story:
Winter Stations is back!

If you have not already heard, Winter Stations is an annual public art competition that challenges designers worldwide to reimagine Toronto's lifeguard stations as a basis for winter art. Take a look at the 1000+ photos tagged at last year's event!

In its inaugural year, Winter Stations received nearly 200 submissions from 36 countries around the world. Four winning stations and a student-contribution from Ryerson University debuted on Family Day turning The Beach into a wintertime destination for design enthusiasts and families alike. The response was astounding. Media coverage stretched around the world, including stories in Dwell, Financial Times, Design Boom, Dezeen, Arch Daily and inclusion in Nanotecture (Phaidon Press).

Now in its second year, Winter Stations has once again called on the world’s designers and they have answered in spades. The second annual Winter Stations competition almost doubled last year’s participation amount, with 372 submissions coming from 49 countries. With the jury selection already taking place, the Winter Stations team is busy planning the design concepts that will become fully-realized installations in February 2016.


Take Ownership

This year, we want to involve YOU - By donating, you are effectively taking ownership of the stations and proving that small design initiatives like this one can flourish in Toronto.


Please share this page. With your help, we can reinvigorate the city this winter and prod Torontonians back outside.

For more information, visit the website at: http://winterstations.com

What We Need & What You Get

The following is a breakdown of the costs to produce a station:

$3,500 designer’s honorarium
Up to $1,500 travel and accommodation allowance
$11,300 ($10,000 + HST) materials and labour 
Up to $1,695 ($1,500 + HST) in engineering fees

Total: $18,000

The cost to cover all 13 stations is $234,000 so we’re fundraising one station at a time with this campaign.

If we come short of funding a station (or If we miraculously surpass our funding goals) we will put the money towards the events and celebration. 

We are offering the following perks:

$5 – Thank you
$10 – 6x4” postcard of a winning station of your choice
$15 – 11x17” poster of a winning station of your choice
$20 – Poster and postcard of a winning station of your choice 
$50 – Postcard set of all of the stations and your name on a special thank you sign erected on-site
$50 – Poster set of all of the stations and your name on a special thank you sign erected on-site
$100 – All postcards, posters, a copy of Nanotecture (Phaidon Press) and your name on a special thank you sign erected on-site
$500 – All postcards, posters a copy of Nanotecture (Phaidon Press) private meet-and-greet with the winning artists and sponsors, and your name on a special thank you sign erected on-site
$1000 - All postcards, posters, a copy of Nanotecture (Phaidon Press), private meet-and-greet with the winning artists and sponsors, invitation to the after-party, your name on a special thank you sign erected on-site and a special mention on the website
$3000 - All postcards, posters, a copy of Nanotecture (Phaidon Press), private meet-and-greet with the winning artists and sponsors, invitation to the after-party and a special mention on the website

This project isn't just important for Toronto - It is a budding winter event that we hope to turn into a worldwide movement. By helping fund this project, you’re supporting art that shapes our winter culture.  


Selected Press

http://www.dwell.com/great-idea/article/mini-structures-are-winter-equivalent-lifeguard-stationhttp://www.azuremagazine.com/article/now-torontos-wonderful-winter-stations/

http://www.designboom.com/architecture/winter-stations-toronto-03-03-2015/

http://www.designboom.com/architecture/snowcone-winter-stations-raw-design-ferris-curio-toronto-kew-beach-02-35-2015/

http://designlinesmagazine.com/winter-stations/

http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2015/01/13/warming_huts_to_transform_lifeguard_stations_on_toronto_beach.html

http://urbantoronto.ca/news/2015/02/winter-stations-now-display-kew-and-balmy-beaches

http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/photos/whimsical-warming-stations-dot-toronto-s-beach-1.2963426

http://www.archdaily.com/605271/winter-stations-bring-warmth-to-toronto-s-frozen-beaches

http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/news-video/video-toronto-beach-huts/article23132176/

http://www.canadianarchitect.com/architecture/finalists-revealed-in-torontos-inaugural-winter-stations-design-competition/1003430215/

http://www.insidetoronto.com/news-story/5261507-lifeguard-stations-in-the-beach-to-become-whimsical-winter-art-installations/

http://www.livewithculture.ca/art/winter-stations-warm-up-the-beach/

http://www.beachmetro.com/2015/02/16/winter-stations-transform-beach-artistic-warming-stations/

http://www.dezeen.com/2015/03/02/winter-stations-toronto-frozen-beaches-converted-lifeguard-towers-pavilions-installations-swings/

The Organizers

Roland Rom Colthoff – RAW Design Architects
Ted Merrick – Ferris + Associates Landscape Architects
Justin Ridgeway – Curio Art Consultants
Aaron Hendershott – RAW Design Architects
Mary-Margaret McMahon – City of Toronto
Edward Birnbaum – City of Toronto
Tomek Chwieszczenik – Ferris + Associates Landscape Architects


Media and Events:
Vakis Boutsalis – Kim Graham & Associates
Kim Graham - Kim Graham & Associates
