story:
Project Background

The health of both the Missouri and Hudson Rivers - their tributaries and the vast watersheds and populations they support - are threatened by oil and gas pipelines - those currently operational, and those currently in proposal or incomplete - to transport highly volatile and toxic fracked crude oil and gasses from such places as the Bakken Shale Formation in North Dakota. Myriad oil and gas pipelines in various stages of operation and development, represent an expanding threat of great magnitude both nationwide and internationally to our global fresh water supply.  As our country faces critical choices about the energy infrastructures we invest in and support, it is imperative to have public, open, informed, and creative dialogue about pressing dangers, available options, and viable pathways for actions to help realize greater social-environmental justice. I hold that these conversations can be deepened, enriched, and motivated in part by direct experiences in acts of ritual and participatory art.

My name is Elizabeth Phelps Meyer. I am an interdisciplinary artist and art educator who lives and works in Poughkeepsie, NY. I work in ceramic installation, sculpture, and experimental animation, and also with interactive projects that explore community.

This project, Each Day, Water has been my heart's response to three interwoven crises: the water crisis of industrial pollution and waste from fossil-fuel extraction practices and pipelines; climate change due to global fossil fuel economies; and the persistent, ongoing forms of violence that indigenous people face. This project aims to celebrate indigenous resistance to these forms of violence; the indigenous sovereignty and leadership so necessary for restoring balance in this world; and to foster constructive ally-consciousness among non-native people.

Community events, offered for free or with a modest suggested donation, will take place at the gallery during the exhibition. These events will include:

*A slide lecture called "River People" by acclaimed historian, author, poet, musician and professor Evan Pritchard. Evan will present a slide show and talk about the river people (Munsee Delaware, Wappingers, Tappan, Mohican) of the mid-Hudson Valley

*Concert of traditional songs by Kontiwennahawi: the Mohawk Women Singers of Akwesasne

*Storytelling and song with Joan Henry, Earthsinger

* A Roundtable Discussion on Decolonization, with indigenous scholars, art historian, artist/s, educators, and activists: Molly McGlennan (moderator), Crystal Migwans, Joan Henry, Two Clouds, Jennifer Weston, and others TBC

*Screenings of documentaries: Black Snake Killaz and Awake: A Dream from Standing Rock, with guests TBD

* A closing ceremony and 1-mile walk from the gallery to the river with Standing Rock Water Protector Chas Jewett, who has been long-practicing traditional water ceremonies with Ojibwe elder Sharon Day, leader of Nibi Walks

*Other possible events TBA

Contributors to this campaign will help me realize a project that, at the time of exhibition, will have been two years in-the-making. This project will feature a gallery installation of 365 wood-fired ceramic vessels, the best among those that I have made on a regular basis since October, 2016. Each vessel in the exhibition will symbolize one day of the solar year. These cup-like forms remind people of the necessity for clean water, each day.

In the exhibition, 328 cups will contain water from Standing Rock, the Missouri/ Mni Sose and Cannonball/ Inyanwakagapi Wakpa Rivers. This quantity reflects the number of days the camps at Standing Rock were active, from April 1, 2016 to February 22, 2017.  In the gallery, the slowly evaporating water will evoke impermanence and suffuse the intimate space with the energies and smells of these rivers. The remaining 37 vessels will contain water from other significant sites of indigenous and allied struggles against perilous fossil fuel pipeline infrastructure: the "Black Snake."

Woven into the exhibition will be approximately twenty-five oral statements of powerful indigenous Water Protectors and several of their non-native allies, who wished to participate in sharing messages with the audience for this exhibit. If the water is the life-blood, then these spoken statements form the heart of the exhibition, and participants will be able to hear them using headphone sets provided in the gallery.

There will be centrally-placed cups in the gallery into which participants can bring water from their own homes or from aquatic environments they cherish. These diverse water offerings will blend with water from the sources in this exhibition.

During the closing event, on Saturday, October 27, 2018, participants will be invited to choose a vessel from the exhibit to keep  and at this time, participants will also have the opportunity to make a donation to the development of the Mní Wičhóni Nakíčižin (Defenders of the Water School) for children at the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation, which started at the Oceti Sakowin Prayer Camp. We will then make a one-mile ceremonial walk with Standing Rock Water Protector, Chas Jewett, who has been long-practicing traditional water walks and ceremonies with Ojibwe elder Sharon Day.* Chas will lead the group from Art Centro to Waryas Park on the Hudson waterfront in the City of Poughkeepsie. In this walk and closing ceremony, participants will join the water from the exhibition with that of the flowing Hudson/Muhheakantuc.

Water in the exhibit will carry the energy and prayers from the following sites:

- Standing Rock Sioux Reservation:  the Missouri/ Mni Sose and Cannonball/ Inyanwakagapi Wakpa Rivers (#nodapl)

- Headwaters* of the Hudson/ Muhheakantuc at Lake Tear of the Clouds in the Adirondacks (#nopilgrimpipelines #stopspectra)

- Ramapo River, site of the Ramapough Lenape Split Rock Sweet Water Prayer Camp (#nopilgrimpipelines #stopspectra)

- Headwaters* of the Mississippi from Lake Itasca, MN (#nobayoubridge #nodapl #noline3)

- The Cheyenne River (#nokxl)

- Lake Superior (#noline3)

* Note: This teaching is courtesy of Sharon Day: The headwaters are clean, fresh, pure. So taking this clean water and giving it back to the river at either the mouth of the river (as we do in the nibi walks) or to a point of pollution along the course of a river (as we will on October 27 in Poughkeepsie) is "“Giving her a taste of herself.” The mouth of a river (zaageeng in Ojibwe): translates as “Place where all life comes for nurturing." Today the mouths of rivers are polluted “dead zones.” Water flows only in a sacred direction, we are the ones who pollute it, we must detoxify it. We wish to give the river a taste of herself – from the beginning to now. These walks show the water spirits that there are still people who love. When the headwater spirits come to the mouth-of-the-river spirits they confer, they let them know there are still people who love. Love is a healing grace."

Project Background:

As news from the Prayer Camps of Standing Rock intensified in October, 2016, it became imperative I demonstrate solidarity with Water Protectors, who persisted in prayer, ceremony, and non-violent forms of resistance to the DAPL despite ongoing abuse by militarized police. I began to make porcelain water cups. I formed each vessel precisely on the potter’s wheel then transformed it with spontaneous visceral gestures: grief, defiance, peaceful resolve.... Some of these cups are thus poised while others embody the distortions and ruptures of violence directed both at the environment and at Water Protectors. This ritual practice became my way of Standing with Standing Rock. Their circles strained to varying degrees, each vessel embodies some of the pressures exerted on the "sacred hoop of life;" not only on our ecosystems, but on our social fabric. Each vessel stands in homage to the Water Protectors' resilience and ongoing dedication. In the words of one Siouxan Water Protector "The entire event - from beginning to end - is a ceremony."

What I Need 

This project is made possible with funds from the Decentralization Program, a regrant program of the New York State Council on the Arts with the support of Governor Andrew Cuomo and the New York State Legislature and administered by Arts Mid-Hudson. I have also received some professional development funding from the awesome school where I teach, Oakwood Friends School. As all artists do, I've put in many, many hundreds of dollars of my own to create this work and to travel to the Dakotas. However, the expenses to fully realize this project far exceed the funding I have and have gratefully received. I need to raise about $4,000 to close my budget gap. Any less, and I will personally cover the difference. Any more funding raised than this will go to the Mní Wičhóni Nakíčižiŋ Owáyawa (Defenders of Water School) for children of Standing Rock, which started at the Oceti Sakowin Prayer Camp. While I am (truly) embarrassed to have to fundraise to do this work, especially in light of the fact that Water Protectors face so many expenses for meeting their basic needs, I can not realize this project fully on my own. I received the support of Water Protectors to fundraise, saying, "With the blessing of Water Protectors I am going to raise funding to empower amplify their voices and share their medicine."

Your help would be so deeply appreciated. Even if I realize only two-thirds of my goal, this would be an enormous help that would prevent me from going into significant debt to bring this work and event programming to the community.

Funding from this drive will cover these remaining costs:

$2000 - Funding toward hosting events (travel stipends, honoraria, and artist fees) with indigenous artists, activists, and scholars in Poughkeepsie during October.

$500 - Funding toward exhibition display shelving and furniture costs.

$150 - Essay commission by Standing Rock Water Protector for exhibition pamphlet.

$550 - Printing costs for postcards, posters, and exhibition pamphlet.

$400 - to assist with a fraction of travel expenses from artist's 2-week travel to visit Oceti Sakowin (Sioux) land in the Dakotas this past July to collect water and record spoken messages from Water Protectors.

$400 - to assist with a fraction of firing fees for wood-firings this summer in NY State, necessary for the artist to bring this body of ceramic work to completion.

You Receive

A donation of any amount helps hugely. You get the reward of knowing that you helped an artist realize their vision and passion. You get to know that you are helping to raise a compassionate and critical awareness of a deeply significant issue of both environmental and social justice. You will also receive, if you help me fund this project with a donation of:

$5+:

*Deep gratitude.
*Your name on a list of donors in the exhibition binder.

$40+:
*Deep gratitude.
*Your name on a list of donors in the exhibition binder.
* A small (3" x 3" circle) Standing Rock Sioux Tribe sticker.

$80+:

*Deep gratitude
*One wood-fired porcelain vessel from the exhibition Each Day, Water and a small vial of waters from the exhibit, after it closes in late October.
*Your name on a list of donors in the exhibition binder.

$250+:

*Deep gratitude
*A grouping of three wood-fired porcelain vessels from the exhibition Each Day, Water  - with a 9" long X 3.5" deep white-stained wood shelf from the exhibit with mounting brackets attached - as well as a small vial of waters from the exhibit, after it closes in late October.
*One private lesson on the potter's wheel (Poughkeepise, NY).
*Your name on a list of donors in the exhibition binder.

$500+:

*Deep gratitude
*A grouping of five wood-fired porcelain vessels from the exhibition Each Day, Water and a small vial of waters from from the exhibit, after it closes in late October.
*I'll meet you in Poughkeepsie to view the exhibition together and get tea or coffee afterwards.
*Three private lessons on the potter's wheel where I work.
*Your name on a list of donors in the exhibition binder.

$1,000+:

*Deep gratitude
*A grouping of seven wood-fired porcelain vessels from the exhibition Each Day, Water and a small vial of water from from the exhibit, after it closes in late October.
*An invitation for you and a friend or family member for a studio visit and a meal at my home in Poughkeepsie, NY.
*Four private lessons on the potter's wheel where I work.
*Your name on a list of donors in the exhibition binder.

The Impact

Your contribution will make a difference:

  • This art project and these community events shine light back on a yet-unresolved issue, to remind us of the ongoing, urgent concerns of the people of Standing Rock and other indigenous communities who face the threat of fossil fuel infrastructure and pipeline expansion projects into regions that impact their sovereign territories and the health and well-being of their communities. Indigenous communities already face many intense challenges, and the unjust threat of industrial pollution compounds these. Their struggle provides a focal point through which citizens of conscience must urgently examine, interrogate, and protest the wide-reaching prevalence of environmental racism. Though ultimately no community is safe from the realities of industrial pollution and the imminent threats of environmental degradation and carbon-based climate change, communities of color, the poor, and indigenous people are often unfairly targeted to bear the burden of this toxicity.
  • The last time I created an interactive ceramic installation, through the generosity of participants, I was able to gather a significant sum to contribute toward the rebuilding of a monastery and nunnery in Kathmandu, after the devastating Nepal earthquakes of April, 2015. I am seeking to raise critical awareness of an issue that has largely left the public eye since the media blackout on the #noDAPL struggle after the Standing Rock Prayer Camps closed in late February, 2017. Participants will also have the opportunity to make a contribution to the development of the Mní Wičhóni Nakíčižiŋ Owáyawa (Defenders of Water School) for children of Standing Rock, which started at the Oceti Sakowin Prayer Camp.
  • Despite the fact that a US District Court in Washington DC found it illegal (last June) that the US Army Corps of Engineers approved Energy Transfer Partners to complete the pipeline construction and begin its operations, hundreds of thousands of gallons of oil still course, EACH DAY, through the Dakota Access Pipeline, threatening water and life. Leaks have already occurred along this pipeline route.
  • The sovereign Sioux Nations (Oceti Sakowin) have been directly and immediately imperiled by this and other pipeline projects (such as the current Keystone XL). The outrage and public outcry must continue as "Standing with Standing Rock" and all the Sioux People (Oyate) is just as urgent now as it was during the time of the Prayer Camps. Many tribal members face ongoing legal prosecution and disproportionately unjust consequences for their peaceful Water Protector activities at the Prayer Camps. The stand against the DAPL and Keystone XL Pipeline continues too - though with a lower profile - at the L'Eau Est La Vie Camp in Louisiana and the (currently dormant) Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe's Wakpa Was'te Prayer Camp, which will re-form as necessary to resist the resurrected Keystone XL pipeline project.
  • Without awareness, and the sharpened sense of urgency brought on by the impact of direct experience, citizens remain silent on these issues. This exhibition and these events push back against this silence and urge each person to reflect on what meaningful action they might take, each in their own way. There will be resources, references, and recommended pathways for action - both locally and nationally - made available at the exhibition and community events.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially to my project, you can still help me realize this vision:

  • Please consider supporting this currently active Water Protector Prayer Camp: L'Eau Est La Vie Camp in the Louisiana swamplands (#noBayouBridge, #noDAPL):
    join camp/ read more: http://nobbp.org/
    camp fund → bit.ly/nobbp
    amazon wishlist → tinyurl.com/nobbpwish
  • Educate yourself about all pipeline battles and clean water struggles that exist locally, nationally, and internationally. Without clean water, life sickens and dies. Join the fight against corporate greed, and local, state, and federal government-sanctioned destruction.
  • Continue to communicate with your elected officials about the urgency of climate change, halting industrial pollution, and the need to curtail the expansion of fossil fuel infrastructure, everywhere, but particularly into zones that impact sovereign indigenous territories/ Treaty lands.
  • Please get the word out and share my campaign with your friends and family; anyone you think would be supportive of this project.
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools to increase my campaign's visibility and success.

From the bottom of my heart, thank you for your interest and support.
story_txt:
Project Background
The health of both the Missouri and Hudson Rivers - their tributaries and the vast watersheds and populations they support - are threatened by oil and gas pipelines - those currently operational, and those currently in proposal or incomplete - to transport highly volatile and toxic fracked crude oil and gasses from such places as the Bakken Shale Formation in North Dakota. Myriad oil and gas pipelines in various stages of operation and development, represent an expanding threat of great magnitude both nationwide and internationally to our global fresh water supply.  As our country faces critical choices about the energy infrastructures we invest in and support, it is imperative to have public, open, informed, and creative dialogue about pressing dangers, available options, and viable pathways for actions to help realize greater social-environmental justice. I hold that these conversations can be deepened, enriched, and motivated in part by direct experiences in acts of ritual and participatory art.
My name is Elizabeth Phelps Meyer. I am an interdisciplinary artist and art educator who lives and works in Poughkeepsie, NY. I work in ceramic installation, sculpture, and experimental animation, and also with interactive projects that explore community.
This project, Each Day, Water has been my heart's response to three interwoven crises: the water crisis of industrial pollution and waste from fossil-fuel extraction practices and pipelines; climate change due to global fossil fuel economies; and the persistent, ongoing forms of violence that indigenous people face. This project aims to celebrate indigenous resistance to these forms of violence; the indigenous sovereignty and leadership so necessary for restoring balance in this world; and to foster constructive ally-consciousness among non-native people.

Community events, offered for free or with a modest suggested donation, will take place at the gallery during the exhibition. These events will include:
*A slide lecture called "River People" by acclaimed historian, author, poet, musician and professor Evan Pritchard. Evan will present a slide show and talk about the river people (Munsee Delaware, Wappingers, Tappan, Mohican) of the mid-Hudson Valley
*Concert of traditional songs by Kontiwennahawi: the Mohawk Women Singers of Akwesasne
*Storytelling and song with Joan Henry, Earthsinger
* A Roundtable Discussion on Decolonization, with indigenous scholars, art historian, artist/s, educators, and activists: Molly McGlennan (moderator), Crystal Migwans, Joan Henry, Two Clouds, Jennifer Weston, and others TBC
*Screenings of documentaries: Black Snake Killaz and Awake: A Dream from Standing Rock, with guests TBD
* A closing ceremony and 1-mile walk from the gallery to the river with Standing Rock Water Protector Chas Jewett, who has been long-practicing traditional water ceremonies with Ojibwe elder Sharon Day, leader of Nibi Walks
*Other possible events TBA
Contributors to this campaign will help me realize a project that, at the time of exhibition, will have been two years in-the-making. This project will feature a gallery installation of 365 wood-fired ceramic vessels, the best among those that I have made on a regular basis since October, 2016. Each vessel in the exhibition will symbolize one day of the solar year. These cup-like forms remind people of the necessity for clean water, each day.
In the exhibition, 328 cups will contain water from Standing Rock, the Missouri/ Mni Sose and Cannonball/ Inyanwakagapi Wakpa Rivers. This quantity reflects the number of days the camps at Standing Rock were active, from April 1, 2016 to February 22, 2017.  In the gallery, the slowly evaporating water will evoke impermanence and suffuse the intimate space with the energies and smells of these rivers. The remaining 37 vessels will contain water from other significant sites of indigenous and allied struggles against perilous fossil fuel pipeline infrastructure: the "Black Snake."
Woven into the exhibition will be approximately twenty-five oral statements of powerful indigenous Water Protectors and several of their non-native allies, who wished to participate in sharing messages with the audience for this exhibit. If the water is the life-blood, then these spoken statements form the heart of the exhibition, and participants will be able to hear them using headphone sets provided in the gallery.
There will be centrally-placed cups in the gallery into which participants can bring water from their own homes or from aquatic environments they cherish. These diverse water offerings will blend with water from the sources in this exhibition.
During the closing event, on Saturday, October 27, 2018, participants will be invited to choose a vessel from the exhibit to keep  and at this time, participants will also have the opportunity to make a donation to the development of the Mní Wičhóni Nakíčižin (Defenders of the Water School) for children at the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation, which started at the Oceti Sakowin Prayer Camp. We will then make a one-mile ceremonial walk with Standing Rock Water Protector, Chas Jewett, who has been long-practicing traditional water walks and ceremonies with Ojibwe elder Sharon Day.* Chas will lead the group from Art Centro to Waryas Park on the Hudson waterfront in the City of Poughkeepsie. In this walk and closing ceremony, participants will join the water from the exhibition with that of the flowing Hudson/Muhheakantuc.
Water in the exhibit will carry the energy and prayers from the following sites:
- Standing Rock Sioux Reservation:  the Missouri/ Mni Sose and Cannonball/ Inyanwakagapi Wakpa Rivers (#nodapl)
- Headwaters* of the Hudson/ Muhheakantuc at Lake Tear of the Clouds in the Adirondacks (#nopilgrimpipelines #stopspectra)
- Ramapo River, site of the Ramapough Lenape Split Rock Sweet Water Prayer Camp (#nopilgrimpipelines #stopspectra)
- Headwaters* of the Mississippi from Lake Itasca, MN (#nobayoubridge #nodapl #noline3)
- The Cheyenne River (#nokxl)
- Lake Superior (#noline3)
* Note: This teaching is courtesy of Sharon Day: The headwaters are clean, fresh, pure. So taking this clean water and giving it back to the river at either the mouth of the river (as we do in the nibi walks) or to a point of pollution along the course of a river (as we will on October 27 in Poughkeepsie) is "“Giving her a taste of herself.” The mouth of a river (zaageeng in Ojibwe): translates as “Place where all life comes for nurturing." Today the mouths of rivers are polluted “dead zones.” Water flows only in a sacred direction, we are the ones who pollute it, we must detoxify it. We wish to give the river a taste of herself – from the beginning to now. These walks show the water spirits that there are still people who love. When the headwater spirits come to the mouth-of-the-river spirits they confer, they let them know there are still people who love. Love is a healing grace."
Project Background:
As news from the Prayer Camps of Standing Rock intensified in October, 2016, it became imperative I demonstrate solidarity with Water Protectors, who persisted in prayer, ceremony, and non-violent forms of resistance to the DAPL despite ongoing abuse by militarized police. I began to make porcelain water cups. I formed each vessel precisely on the potter’s wheel then transformed it with spontaneous visceral gestures: grief, defiance, peaceful resolve.... Some of these cups are thus poised while others embody the distortions and ruptures of violence directed both at the environment and at Water Protectors. This ritual practice became my way of Standing with Standing Rock. Their circles strained to varying degrees, each vessel embodies some of the pressures exerted on the "sacred hoop of life;" not only on our ecosystems, but on our social fabric. Each vessel stands in homage to the Water Protectors' resilience and ongoing dedication. In the words of one Siouxan Water Protector "The entire event - from beginning to end - is a ceremony."

What I Need 
This project is made possible with funds from the Decentralization Program, a regrant program of the New York State Council on the Arts with the support of Governor Andrew Cuomo and the New York State Legislature and administered by Arts Mid-Hudson. I have also received some professional development funding from the awesome school where I teach, Oakwood Friends School. As all artists do, I've put in many, many hundreds of dollars of my own to create this work and to travel to the Dakotas. However, the expenses to fully realize this project far exceed the funding I have and have gratefully received. I need to raise about $4,000 to close my budget gap. Any less, and I will personally cover the difference. Any more funding raised than this will go to the Mní Wičhóni Nakíčižiŋ Owáyawa (Defenders of Water School) for children of Standing Rock, which started at the Oceti Sakowin Prayer Camp. While I am (truly) embarrassed to have to fundraise to do this work, especially in light of the fact that Water Protectors face so many expenses for meeting their basic needs, I can not realize this project fully on my own. I received the support of Water Protectors to fundraise, saying, "With the blessing of Water Protectors I am going to raise funding to empower amplify their voices and share their medicine."
Your help would be so deeply appreciated. Even if I realize only two-thirds of my goal, this would be an enormous help that would prevent me from going into significant debt to bring this work and event programming to the community.

$2000 - Funding toward hosting events (travel stipends, honoraria, and artist fees) with indigenous artists, activists, and scholars in Poughkeepsie during October.
$500 - Funding toward exhibition display shelving and furniture costs.

$400 - to assist with a fraction of travel expenses from artist's 2-week travel to visit Oceti Sakowin (Sioux) land in the Dakotas this past July to collect water and record spoken messages from Water Protectors.
$400 - to assist with a fraction of firing fees for wood-firings this summer in NY State, necessary for the artist to bring this body of ceramic work to completion.
You Receive
A donation of any amount helps hugely. You get the reward of knowing that you helped an artist realize their vision and passion. You get to know that you are helping to raise a compassionate and critical awareness of a deeply significant issue of both environmental and social justice. You will also receive, if you help me fund this project with a donation of:
$5+:
*Deep gratitude.*Your name on a list of donors in the exhibition binder.
$40+:*Deep gratitude.*Your name on a list of donors in the exhibition binder.* A small (3" x 3" circle) Standing Rock Sioux Tribe sticker.
$80+:
*Deep gratitude*One wood-fired porcelain vessel from the exhibition Each Day, Water and a small vial of waters from the exhibit, after it closes in late October.*Your name on a list of donors in the exhibition binder.
$250+:
*Deep gratitude*A grouping of three wood-fired porcelain vessels from the exhibition Each Day, Water  - with a 9" long X 3.5" deep white-stained wood shelf from the exhibit with mounting brackets attached - as well as a small vial of waters from the exhibit, after it closes in late October.*One private lesson on the potter's wheel (Poughkeepise, NY).*Your name on a list of donors in the exhibition binder.

story:
KEKASA     UNIQUE   TABLES  

          MANUFACTURING                  

  Hello my name is Kevin. I have a passion for working with wood. I have been doing this for many years now,  it has been a hobby of mine for a long time. I love to create new designs with wood and on wood. As you can see with the picture above, I like to create unique designs, each one is exclusive, hard to duplicate, one of a kind. Its like getting a painting from a famous painter, its an original one, nothing the same. It is like a Van-go or Rembrandt one of a kind.

 I take all coloured woods cut them in to different lengths and shapes then laminate them together, in unique patterns to make the table tops, as you can see in the one picture I have, unfortunately I lost the flash drive the others were on, not to happy about that, their where a lot of tables on that flash drive, that I could have showed every one. But think you will still get the idea of what I can do with a table tops.

  My dream is to make this my soul business, and it's very important at this time in my life. I have a lot of new ideas in my head and I am always thinking of new ones. All I want from this business, is to make a decent living, I don't need to make a million a year, just enough to live comfortably. This is a passion of mine. Building these tables, makes me feel good about my self, makes me happy. I love creating new designs, on the table tops, for people to injoy and show off to there friends, to look at, and have them say wow, that is remarkable. That's why I want this to happen for me, that's why its important, to me. It makes me feel good.   You as contributors can make my dream come true and goal come true for me. You as contributors will help me buy the equipment needed, such as a big drum sander, cnc router, table saws, chop saws, band saws, office equipment, and much, much, more equipment needed and possibly, if enough raised, to buy or build a building big enough to hold the equipment, needed to build these tables. You as contributors can realy make this dream happen for me. Here are pictures of some equipment needed plus there will be much, much, more needed. 



    Please read and look further in to my campaign you will see some different ideas, that I'd like to convey on the table tops, for people to enjoy, for many years. The table tops I do are more exclusive, unique, rare and one of a kind, like the table you see next.


 Thank you from the bottom of my heart for contributing to my campaign.

   This is a new start up business. It is manufacturing unique tables  of  designs made up of different coloured hard and soft woods. The tables could also be inlaid  with different pictures on top of your choice, such as wild life, and family , etc. as you will see at the end of the campaign.

   I also do conventional tables as well.

 They come in sizes from 3 feet wide, to 8 feet long, I am looking to advertise via web site and news paper, across Canada and the USA. etc.. to reach out to a broader scope of costumers, once up and running.

      I am looking to raise $225,000.00 dollars, to start this company up for all the equipment needed and advertising needed for the first year.                      The ultimate goal would be to raise enough money to get a building that would be big enough for this business, all though the equipment comes first, that is the most inportent right now.

       Please send all emails to this email address regarding any questions or for a pre order of a table of your choice.  kekasauniquetables@gmail.com

     To pre order a table in advance please feel free to email that to my email address above.

Prices will vary. For instance, say you want one 8 foot long abstract table, which is like the first table you just seen up above; it is normally $3400.00. If you pre order now you can get an abstract table that size for $2700.00, that is a $700.00 dollar savings. Now if you got a 6 foot abstract table it would be $2400.00 regular $2900.00, and if you got a 4 foot abstract one, thats an apartment size table it would be $2100.00, regular $2500.00, and a abstract coffee table for $1500.00 regular $2100.00. And conventional tables start at $1800.00 and work there way down as well. 

 I will even throw in some unique  coasters and a cutting board with any pre order.

 I will save the emails and you will be contacted when up and running for more info.

 Thank you for funding kekasa unique tables manufacturing.

    May many new things happen in the very near future with this business venture.

 Thank you and god bless you all for helping me with my dream.

   Here are some sample pictures of some tables, that  I do. I am more exclusive to the table that you see at the top, and the one on the front cover. I would have had more pictures like the abstract  ones  I have done, like the top table, but I seem to have lost my flash drive I had them on, not to happy about that.   There are many ideas that I come up with and these are just some of them, please scoll down look through them all. 

here are some other things ill be doing on the table tops. these are just some ideas im throwing out there , just used what i had to work with on a very low budget.

you will see some curl on the pictures that i didnt notice, but the real ones will be inlaid on real wood, and only stains or paints used if requested, the pictures once up and running can be the same size as the tables, to look like a big picture or mural,

can also put quotes on the table a little bigger of course

can also do wild life pictures  and they can also be bigger and up to the same size as the table



can also do up your family or wedding pics as well these pictures you see have some curl, the way i do them on a table top they are inlaid on top not like these, these are just exsamples what else you could do on a table top.

now this one I wasnt sure if i should put in , but was thinking that if any of these sold i would donnate $500 dollars to the fondation looking after the victoms families.

now here are some more ideas, i thought they looked realy cool


now just remember i have many ideas for the tables.

Thank you for looking over my campaign and contributeing to it , may this indever take off with flying colours and be a successful one, thank you and god bless you all for helping me with my dream come true.

It is manufacturing unique tables  of  designs made up of different coloured hard and soft woods. The tables could also be inlaid  with different pictures on top of your choice, such as wild life, and family , etc. as you will see at the end of the campaign.   I also do conventional tables as well. They come in sizes from 3 feet wide, to 8 feet long, I am looking to advertise via web site and news paper, across Canada and the USA. etc.. to reach out to a broader scope of costumers, once up and running.      I am looking to raise $225,000.00 dollars, to start this company up for all the equipment needed and advertising needed for the first year.                      The ultimate goal would be to raise enough money to get a building that would be big enough for this business, all though the equipment comes first, that is the most inportent right now.       Please send all emails to this email address regarding any questions or for a pre order of a table of your choice.  kekasauniquetables@gmail.com
     To pre order a table in advance please feel free to email that to my email address above.Prices will vary. For instance, say you want one 8 foot long abstract table, which is like the first table you just seen up above; it is normally $3400.00. If you pre order now you can get an abstract table that size for $2700.00, that is a $700.00 dollar savings. Now if you got a 6 foot abstract table it would be $2400.00 regular $2900.00, and if you got a 4 foot abstract one, thats an apartment size table it would be $2100.00, regular $2500.00, and a abstract coffee table for $1500.00 regular $2100.00. And conventional tables start at $1800.00 and work there way down as well.  I will even throw in some unique  coasters and a cutting board with any pre order. I will save the emails and you will be contacted when up and running for more info. Thank you for funding kekasa unique tables manufacturing.    May many new things happen in the very near future with this business venture. Thank you and god bless you all for helping me with my dream.   Here are some sample pictures of some tables, that  I do. I am more exclusive to the table that you see at the top, and the one on the front cover. I would have had more pictures like the abstract  ones  I have done, like the top table, but I seem to have lost my flash drive I had them on, not to happy about that.   There are many ideas that I come up with and these are just some of them, please scoll down look through them all. 







here are some other things ill be doing on the table tops. these are just some ideas im throwing out there , just used what i had to work with on a very low budget.
you will see some curl on the pictures that i didnt notice, but the real ones will be inlaid on real wood, and only stains or paints used if requested, the pictures once up and running can be the same size as the tables, to look like a big picture or mural, 
can also put quotes on the table a little bigger of course


can also do wild life pictures  and they can also be bigger and up to the same size as the table






can also do up your family or wedding pics as well these pictures you see have some curl, the way i do them on a table top they are inlaid on top not like these, these are just exsamples what else you could do on a table top.






now this one I wasnt sure if i should put in , but was thinking that if any of these sold i would donnate $500 dollars to the fondation looking after the victoms families.


now here are some more ideas, i thought they looked realy cool





now just remember i have many ideas for the tables.
Thank you for looking over my campaign and contributeing to it , may this indever take off with flying colours and be a successful one, thank you and god bless you all for helping me with my dream come true.

story:
Come with us... into the most fertile grounds of The Playa.

The Fertility Forest's wisteria-shaded, forest lounge will offer a much needed respite from the desert sun.  Our content will center around exploring our limitless potential, nourishing & optimizing creativity through self care, soul connection, clearing physical & metaphysical toxins & optimizing fertility in all forms.

Exact Location & Schedule will be sent to you when it's all set!  We love hearing from you!  Reach out with any q's, suggestions & to create with us:  TheFertilityForest@gmail.com

Programming Beta :

  • Womb-Space Meditation
  • Sound Bathing & Vibrational Tuning
  • Elemental Nutrient Infusion: Earth, Air, Water, Fire
  • Quantum Field Fertilization & Tending Practices
  • Special Guest Speakers & Performances
  • Curated Library & Lounge to Explore

We are prepared ... 

To take on the harsh conditions of the playa.  We know how challenging it can be to build something that lasts at Burning Man.  Our team includes veterans with 10 years + of living &  building on the playa.  Like anything, there is a lot to take into consideration for the build:  Rain.  Wind.  Sun.  Intoxicated Humans.  All the things.  We are consulting with our network who has extensive experience building in Burning Man to create an exceptional space for us to flourish. *** The more funds we raise, the more nourishing & abundant experience we can dream to life!!

Can't Donate?  We Need Your Help!

There is so much that needs to be done we could use your help. 

There are farmers markets galore with empty egg crates just waiting to find a home!  We need your help hitting the 12p - 2p time-slot at farmers markets to swoop those empty cartons from our loving egg vendors.  Many egg vendors have already donated and are joyfully looking forward to up-cycling their "waste".

We also need help cutting, dying & stringing the egg cartons.  We promise that we will be so much fun to hang out with, that you'll love coming to our divine egg-dying gatherings.

We need hosts. Experts. People to share their stories. Join our team!  Help Host the whole enchilada!  We need you if you are interested at all, let's talk!

Please email us at TheFertilityForest@gmail.com to volunteer!

story:
The Nitty Gritty 

• Diane Da Costa, a celebrity stylist and curly hair expert, has been glamorizing women for the past 30 years. She is the author of the book Textured Tresses, and the founder of the CurlyTexturedBAR, which will open in Harlem this summer, 2018. 

• Previously Diane opened the first multi-textured Aveda concept salon in Manhattan, and she currently owns her own salon, SimpleeBEAUTIFUL CurlyTexturedBAR in Westchester, New York.

• As a curly, textured hair expert, Diane is all about beautifying, educating and styling curly, textured hair. Over the years, Diane has created a community where women with wavy, curly and coily hair can embrace their natural beauty, exchange meaningful conversations and purchase botanical haircare products. 

• The CurlyTexturedBAR will offer a beauty experience with consultations, coloring, cuts, new hair technology, hair extensions, treatments, express blow-outs and textured styling.

• In a fast-paced society, having access to a one-stop-shop that also sells high-end botanical hair products is an important option for women to experience. The CurlyTexturedBAR will provide curly girls with a place to chill, commune and get pampered, while purchasing beauty products, hair accessories and tools designed for women with multi-textured hair. 

• The CurlyTexturedBAR will bring much needed beauty services, specifically for natural and curly women to Harlem!

• The salon will also educate young, talented people from the community who want to acquire a natural hair specialist & advanced training in cutting and styling curly, textured hair.

 

What We Need & What You Get

▪ A total of $3,000 is needed to fund this campaign. Contributions will be used to provide training for staff so that they can service all of our guests in the most efficient way, plus training specifically for blow-outs, textured styling, color and cutting techniques.

• Our unique perks include makeover packages executed by Diane Da Costa, a limited-edition, DYAKIM Textured Turban towel (the best quick-dry microfiber hair towel on the market), and VIP entrance to the exclusive fundraising party for the CurlyTexturedBAR!

• All funds will be used to train coordinators, administrative staff and stylists.

• In addition, a portion of the proceeds raised from this crowd funding campaign will be donated to Diane’s favorite charity, The Juvenile Diabetes Foundation!

 

The Impact

While there are several blow-dry bars throughout Manhattan, the CurlyTexturedBAR will be the first and only salon offering blow-outs, ceramic and textured styling in Harlem specifically for wavy, curly and coily hair textures. Harlem women will now be able to get the best luxury and express services that are offered to the rest of New York in a fun and sexy environment. Guests will also be able to relax with and have a cocktail in hand! Those who require “express service” will be serviced within 90 to 120 minutes. Your contribution will provide invaluable training to staff and employees who are predominately from our community.

 

Risks & Challenges

The CurlyTexturedBAR is scheduled to open in Harlem this summer 2018, but construction can be unpredictable. All rewards will be honored when the salon opens.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Diane thanks you all for your contributions! Even if you can’t contribute monetarily you can still help her achieve her goal. Just get the word out and share this campaign with your friends! You can use IndieGoGo’s social media tools to make it super easy.

story:
About Me...

Hello! My name is Liz and I'm an artist based between NYC and London. I received my BFA in Photography in 2012 from the Hartford Art School. Since then I've exhibited internationally, received various press and given artist talks about my work because it's important that my art creates a dialogue. 

This year I decided that it was time to push myself to the next level, so I applied and was accepted into the prestigious Goldsmiths College in London to pursue their Masters in Fine Art program. I couldn't be more excited about this achievement but need financial support to fully realize my goal. Your support not only will help me to pursue my Masters degree but will enable me to strengthen and expand my voice while spreading my message to a wider audience.

 

What I Need & What You Get

I have been saving up funds for my Masters degree for the past two years and was able to secure a student loan for $20,000 to cover my first year of studies. (The MFA program is 2 years) However I need an additional $40,000 to fund my second year. Here's a breakdown of my costs:

Year 2 Expenses

$28,630 Tuition (MFA 2YR)

$10,000 Living

$3,000 Projected Art Supplies

I'm asking for $27,650 to cover half my total tuition and help with art supplies for next year, however I still have expenses for living, supplies and tuition I'm funding myself.

Any additional funds raised over my goal will be used towards my student loans, art supplies and a donation to a local LGBTQ advocacy organization.

Rewards for you!

I've designed reward levels ranging from limited edition prints to commissioned portraits and a  personal studio visit.

The print pieces are a great way to invest in my art early on and the commissioned work can be a portrait of you or a gift to a loved one! 

 

The Impact

I feel so lucky and love that my art is able to create a dialogue about the way we see ourselves and each other. From the various press, interviews, exhibitions, publications and artist talks I've done, it means the world to me that I can spread my message. By helping me with my MFA you will be able to help expand my art to an even wider audience.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute but still want to help you can! Please help me get the word out by sharing my campaign among your friends and through social media. Any form of support means so much to me. Thank you!! <3

story:
"Looking back at my life's voyage, I can only say that it has been a golden trip." -Ginger Rogers

Note: this campaign will continue indefinitely as we will have ongoing expenses.

Buy a Brick to Help Preserve Ginger Rogers’ Birthplace

When you purchase a brick, you'll be helping us improve Ginger Rogers' birthplace - and turn it into a museum so that everyone can visit the site. Don't worry if our initial campaign does not meet its goal - the project WILL go on, and will continue after that. We have additional assistance coming in from other sources. 

The house is was listed as an Historic Landmark in 2003 by the City of Independence, Missouri.

The house was built in 1906, and Virginia Katherine McMath (later to become Ginger Rogers) was born here in July 16, 1911. She lived in Independence in this house for about two years with her mother, Lela, who was a writer for a local newspaper, then a film screenwriter in Hollywood. Ginger lived with her grandparents in Kansas City until age 9 when her mother, Lela, took her to Fort Worth, Texas where Ginger was "discovered." 

Rogers was well known for her dance films with Fred Astaire, and was a talented singer, dancer, and actress. Her films are still loved by generations of fans. Rogers revisited this home in 1994 for her birthday celebration put on by the city of Independence and Mayor Ron Stewart for "Ginger Rogers Day". She died on April 25, 1995 at the age of 83.


What We Need & What You Get

We think that tourists and residents of Independence, Missouri, will enjoy seeing this site while visiting other local historic landmarks such as the Truman Presidential Library, Truman Home, Vaile Mansion, 1859 Jail, and the historic Independence Square. This site is located not far from all of these important places. Tour buses often drive by the home now-- imagine the response when people can get out and go through the house!

Since this is an historic property with Landmark status, any major or cosmetic change must be approved by the Heritage Commission. This includes zoning changes through the city, getting approval for cosmetic and structural changes, hiring an architect for an addition to be built, paying for plans, and getting approval from the neighbors for the planned improvements. All of this costs money and we'll need to hire an attorney, architect, designer, and subcontractors. This is the first step in making this all happen so the public can enjoy visiting this historic home and museum. 

If we get approval to move forward with the project we may return to request more funds to do exterior landscaping, parking, and site improvements. If we don't get approval for plan A, we will request rezoning to turn the site into a vacation rental or open house museum so people can still visit, and for a marker to be placed on the corner of the lot. All of the money received will be put to good use. We are keeping this project open for continued donations since we'll need operating capital on an ongoing basis. 

UPDATE 2/26/2016: Our initial visit with the City planning department and Heritage Commission went very well and so far there are no objections!

Our Plans for the Property: 

Phase I

1. Purchase the property (DONE!)

2. Obtain rezoning or a special use permit, obtain permission to do site improvements, hire an attorney and architect. 

Phase II

1. Repair drainage issues, plumbing, and replace old knob and tube wiring. Update: the wiring is completed!
2. Repair or replace the front porch floor and supports and replace the front door.
3. Install a great period-looking iron or metal fence around the property for security. 
4, Improve the landscaping and install lighting and brick sidewalks.
5. Create off -street parking with paver bricks.
6. Make the interior a museum of Ginger Roger's life with objects she owned, posters, memorabilia, photos, and descriptions. If possible, we will put a small gift shop inside so people can purchase memorabilia and photos. 
7. Rebuild the brick chimney as it was in 1911. Update: The existing chimney is completely blocked, backing up Carbon Monoxide into the home. We are fixing this right now. 
8. Install handicap accessible ramps and sidewalks.
9. Update: Install under floor supports, install masonry supports on two stone foundation walls (this is something we were not expecting!)

Luckily we were able to obtain a 1942 LIFE magazine with the story of Ginger Rogers and a photos of the house as it was at that time. This will help greatly when doing improvements to restore the house as it was. 

Phase III

We plan to purchase a local historic building to turn into a museum of Independence and if space is available the museum may expand to include Jackson County. A place for Ginger Rogers is planned at that location as well. This will spark interest in visiting her birthplace. 
 ___________________________________________________________________________

LIFE Magazine March 2, 1942 photo of the house. This will go a long way in helping us restore it to how it looked originally. Note the chimney which we will rebuild as it was. 

Buy a Brick for Posterity

Buy a Brick and we'll have your name engraved on it - the bricks will be used for the sidewalk and patio improvements on the site. Your brick will be a permanent addition to the project. 
$50 donation: You will get one paver brick with your name (up to 20 characters)
$100 Donation: You will get two paver bricks with the names of your choice (yours and someone else's if desired)
A $500 donation: Friend of Ginger Rogers level. You'll get five bricks with the names of your choice or whatever you would like to say on them, an 8" x 10" photo of Ginger Rogers, and a listing on our website as a friend of the museum.
A $1,000 donation:  Contributor level. You'll get a large clay tile with your name and logo (if desired) up to five lines of wording included, an 8" x 10" photo of Ginger Rogers and a listing on our website as a contributor. 
A $10,000 donation or higher: Benefactor level. You will receive a large clay tile with your name and logo, an 8" x 10" photo of Ginger Rogers, and will be listed as a benefactor with your name on a plaque to be added somewhere on the property (as allowed), and listed on our website as a benefactor. Plus you'll have free admission to the museum for life.
The Impact

Ginger Rogers was born in Independence, Missouri to Lela and William McMath. McMath was an electrical engineer. Lela did not want to give birth in a hospital so Virginia (Ginger) was born at home. Lela later separated from McMath, who kidnapped Ginger twice before Lela divorced him. Lela left Ginger with her parents in 1915 while she pursued a successful career writing scripts for Fox Studios and later as a theater critic. While living in Texas with her mother Ginger was exposed to the theater and learned how to sing, dance, and actor. Later she became a huge Hollywood Sensation, most notably for her dancing scenes with Fred Astaire.  She was known as "The woman to who could do everything that Fred Astaire did, but backwards and in high heels. "

                                        Photo credit: LIFE Magazine March 2, 1942

Ginger returned to Independence for Ginger Rogers Day on July 16,1994 for her 83rd  birthday celebration. Several thousand fans celebrated with her and Mayor Ron Stewart presented her with a key to the city. A photo was taken of Ginger in front of this house (we are trying to obtain it).

The house she was born in was in private hands and used as a residence until we placed an offer on it and we take possession on February 29!. Our goal is to make this a place that everyone can visit since it is an important part of the history of Independence. 

Risks & Challenges and What you Need to Know about us

As mentioned above, we have several challenges to meet before this project can become a reality, but with the interest in preservation of historic landmarks in this area, we are certain that we can overcome any obstacles. It just takes money and perseverance.  

With our experience in the contracting business for 33 years and buying, restoring, and renting or selling houses for 10 years, we will be overseeing the entire project from start to finish. We have the expertise and connections with other professionals to make this happen. To see more about who we are please visit our company websites www.threetrailscottages.com and www.chimkc.com.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please ask all your friends and relatives to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.

  • Donate Items to the Museum: If you happen to have any Ginger Rogers memorabilia or objects that she owned or wore that you would like to donate to the museum, we'd love to have it and we'll take good care of it!  We are in particular looking for at least one of the gowns she wore in a film to put under a glass case. We will place a brick or tile on the site with your name on it and add your name to the list of contributors on our website.

  • Follow our Twitter account for cool pics and info @GingerRgsMuseum

step in making this all happen so the public can enjoy visiting this historic
home and museum. 
If we get approval to move forward with the project we may return to request more funds to do exterior
landscaping, parking, and site improvements. If we don't get approval for plan A, we
will request rezoning to turn the site into a vacation rental or open house museum so people can
still visit, and for a marker to be placed on the corner of the lot. All of the money received will be put to good use. We are keeping this project open for continued donations since we'll need operating capital on an ongoing basis. 
UPDATE 2/26/2016: Our initial visit with the City planning department and Heritage Commission went very well and so far there are no objections!
Our Plans for the Property: 
Phase I
1. Purchase the property (DONE!)
2. Obtain rezoning or a special use permit, obtain permission to do site improvements, hire an attorney and architect. 
Phase II
1. Repair drainage issues, plumbing, and replace old knob and tube wiring. Update: the wiring is completed!2. Repair or replace the front porch floor and supports and replace the front door.3. Install a great period-looking iron or metal fence around the property for security. 4, Improve the landscaping and install lighting and brick sidewalks.5. Create off -street parking with paver bricks.6. Make the interior a museum of Ginger Roger's life with objects she owned, posters, memorabilia, photos, and descriptions. If possible, we will put a small gift shop inside so people can purchase memorabilia and photos. 7. Rebuild the brick chimney as it was in 1911. Update: The existing chimney is completely blocked, backing up Carbon Monoxide into the home. We are fixing this right now. 8. Install handicap accessible ramps and sidewalks.9. Update: Install under floor supports, install masonry supports on two stone foundation walls (this is something we were not expecting!)Luckily we were able to obtain a 1942 LIFE magazine with the story of Ginger Rogers and a photos of the house as it was at that time. This will help greatly when doing improvements to restore the house as it was. 
Phase III
We plan to purchase a local historic building to turn into a museum of Independence and if space is available the museum may expand to include Jackson County. A place for Ginger Rogers is planned at that location as well. This will spark interest in visiting her birthplace.  ___________________________________________________________________________


LIFE Magazine March 2, 1942 photo of the house. This will go a long way in helping us restore it to how it looked originally. Note the chimney which we will rebuild as it was. 
Buy a Brick for Posterity
  Buy a Brick and we'll have your name engraved on it - the bricks will be used for the sidewalk and patio improvements on the site. Your brick will be a permanent addition to the project. 
$50 donation: You will get one paver brick with your name (up to 20 characters)
$100 Donation: You will get two paver bricks with the names of your choice (yours and someone else's if desired)
A $500 donation: Friend of Ginger Rogers level. You'll get five bricks with the names of your choice or whatever you would like to say on them, an 8" x 10" photo of Ginger Rogers, and a listing on our website as a friend of the museum.
A $1,000 donation:  Contributor level. You'll get a large clay tile with your name and logo (if desired) up to five lines of wording included, an 8" x 10" photo of Ginger Rogers and a listing on our website as a contributor. 
A $10,000 donation or higher: Benefactor level. You will receive a large clay tile with your name and logo, an 8" x 10" photo of Ginger Rogers, and will be listed as a benefactor with your name on a plaque to be added somewhere on the property (as allowed), and listed on our website as a benefactor. Plus you'll have free admission to the museum for life.
The Impact


Ginger Rogers was born in Independence, Missouri to Lela and William McMath. McMath was an electrical engineer. Lela did not want to give birth in a hospital so Virginia (Ginger) was born at home. Lela later separated from McMath, who kidnapped Ginger twice before Lela divorced him. Lela left Ginger with her parents in 1915 while she pursued a successful career writing scripts for Fox Studios and later as a theater critic. While living in Texas with her mother Ginger was exposed to the theater and learned how to sing, dance, and actor. Later she became a huge Hollywood Sensation, most notably for her dancing scenes with Fred Astaire.  She was known as "The woman to who could do everything that Fred Astaire did, but backwards and in high heels. "

                                        Photo credit: LIFE Magazine March 2, 1942Ginger returned to Independence for Ginger Rogers Day on July 16,1994 for her 83rd  birthday celebration. Several thousand fans celebrated with her and Mayor Ron Stewart presented her with a key to the city. A photo was taken of Ginger in front of this house (we are trying to obtain it).
The house she was born in was in private hands and used as a residence until we placed an offer on it and we take possession on February 29!. Our goal is to make this a place that everyone can visit since it is an important part of the history of Independence. 
Risks & Challenges and What you Need to Know about us
 As mentioned above, we have several challenges to meet before this project can become a reality, but with the interest in preservation of historic landmarks in this area, we are certain that we can overcome any obstacles. It just takes money and perseverance.  
With our experience in the contracting business for 33 years and buying, restoring, and renting or selling houses for 10 years, we will be overseeing the entire project from start to finish. We have the expertise and connections with other professionals to make this happen. To see more about who we are please visit our company websites www.threetrailscottages.com and www.chimkc.com.
    Other Ways You Can Help 
Please ask all your friends and relatives to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.


Donate Items to the Museum: If you happen to have any Ginger Rogers memorabilia or objects that she owned or wore that you would like to donate to the museum, we'd love to have it and we'll take good care of it!  We are in particular looking for at least one of the gowns she wore in a film to put under a glass case. We will place a brick or tile on the site with your name on it and add your name to the list of contributors on our website.

Follow our Twitter account for cool pics and info @GingerRgsMuseum

story:
THAT ART FAIR was launched in February 2015. Now in it’s second year THAT ART FAIR has geared up to present a very exciting 19 day line up of work by artists from across the African continent and the diaspora.

THAT ART FAIR is an initiative of ART AFRICA magazine. Founded in re-action to the fact that many countries in Africa lack the formal structures of commercial art galleries where artists can exhibit their work and/ or be represented by galleries or dealers, THAT ART FAIR offers them such a platform. Emerging and established can showcase their work in a relaxed but professional environment, here they can be meet directly with collectors, galleries and new audiences alike! The burgeoning contemporary African market is ripe for the picking and growing a young and invested collector base is our aim.

Our call for participation elicited over 165 applications from artsists and galleries from 20 African countries, including Ghana; Mali; Senegal; Brazil; Ethiopia; Egypt; Cote d'Ivoire; Kenya; South Africa; Namibia; Angola; Mauritius and then as far afield as China; Canada; Dubai and Brazil!

THAT ART FAIR presents :

·  Visual art and photography;

·  a Comic art focus curated by Su Opperman and presented by ComicArtAfrica;

·  THAT FILM FOCUS a curated film screening week; an African film collaboration with Shnit

·  Performance art

·  Video art

·  Fashion and Culture curated by SKATTIE

·  Urban art and live painting

·  ARTSUPERMART

·  Workshops and talks- a series of interesting and topical discussions

·  THAT ART PARTY! Set to take place on 19th February 2016 from 20h00 this is the “do not miss out” event of the year. Last year’s (much talked about) party saw a line up that featured luminaries of the art and music world. Keep a watchful eye on our website your for the release of our edgy and eclectic line-up for THAT ART PARTY 2016!

THAT ART PARTY, the official fair celebration is set to take place on the 19th February. Last year’s much talked about party (you can watch a video here)

saw a line up of such luminaries of the art and music world as The Brother Moves On, Spoek Mathambo, Thor Rixon, Champions of the Sonarverse, Skattie DJ Athi Patra Ruga & the Shield and Spear documentary screening.


 Visit our Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/THAT-ART-FAIR) and follow us on Twitter and Instagram @ThatArtFair


WHAT THEY SAID:
-------------------------------------
March 11 2015
http://artmeetscamera.com
- Thuli Gamedze
"That Art Fair created a space for artists that is generally lost in an art fair setup. While work was being sold quite well, the exchange was not only monetary- conversation and interest acted as feasible assets through which to navigate the space, and I would argue that these assets are the ones that prove more valuable to artists who are invariably trying to ‘make shit happen’.
It seems apt therefore that That Art Fair, organized by Art South Africa, went about things very differently. In order to unpack the presented problems, we might look at this event as an artistic intervention that plays with the notion of exchange in South African art markets. If we think of it as such, there is a lot to be pulled from both situations.
I found That Art Fair very refreshing, and this portal into friendly exchange between artists, writers and organisers is something that is rare to observe in the unloving Mother City, and reads almost as a subversion of both the stiff cleanliness of the Art Fair, and the self-conscious ‘cool’ of the young Cape Town art crowd. Perhaps this can all be explained by the fact that at That Art Fair, black artists were exhibiting, and were present in person- not as trophies to white liberal collectors with old money.
Namsa Leuba’s work completely blew my mind in this regard, tacitly owning the fact that, even after much of this discourse has taken place, a black person photographing black people well still remains a revolutionary act within contemporary South Africa. Sadly (but LOL), we must often continue to ask in other Cape Town gallery setups- where are all the black people, except for in the white man’s photographs?
-------------------------------------
That Art Fair was fresh, inspiring, crisp and filled with people eager to connect, to discuss and to make the experience a shared event. At every exhibition space I was greeted, left to browse, but instantly got service when I needed it. I loved the informality of the space but never felt that I was surrounded by anything less than worldclass contemporary art. Congratulations to the organisers and team. But above all a standing ovation to the exhibitors. I cannot wait for next year!
- Theo Kleynhans 


ABOUT ART AFRICA MAGAZINE:

THAT ART FAIR is an initiative of ART AFRICA magazine, the leading and only African contemporary arts magazine to be founded and published from Africa, for Africa, by Africans. Based in Cape Town, South Africa ART AFRICA was founded in 2002 by Brendon and Suzette Bell- Roberts under the title ARTsouthAFRICA magazine. Now in it’s 14th year, the publication is dedicated to the promoting and stimulating a vibrant African creative arts industry. We are committed to actively promoting transformation and cultural understanding; growing art networks and creating opportunities for young artistic talent from the African continent.

www.artafricamagazine.org

ABOUT THE Founders and Directors:

Brendon Bell-Roberts: For the past twenty years Brendon has been designing, curating and publishing. With more than 100 major publications and exhibitions under his belt, he has helped launch the careers of many of South Africa’s top artists and creatives. Together with his wife Suzette he is the founder and publisher of ARTsouthAFRICA magazine, which has evolved into a digital platform in keeping with his focus on the role of creativity, sustainability and positive change in the African digital revolution. Brendon is also co-founder of the Sustain our Africa summit, expo and festival and theChange Agent Communications Consultancy. His projects combine creativity, sustainability and positive change, helping to define the future Africa.

Suzette Bell-Roberts: After completing a BA LLB at the University of Stellenbosch, Suzette practiced law for a number of years. Together with husband Brendon, they co-founded the cutting edge Bell-Roberts Gallery in 1999 and launched ARTsouthAFRICA magazine 3 years later. A passion for work produced by emerging artists committed to exploration and who push the boundaries of their work; an unfaltering commitment to the promotion of the contemporary arts and contemporary culture from Africa and the diaspora now culminates in the launch of THAT ART FAIR. Suzette is currently working towards a Master’s degree in Intellectual Property Law, with a focus on the visual arts.


WHAT YOUR CONTRIBUTION WILL HELP US TO ACHIEVE:

  1. Travel in Africa is expensive. Many of the artists who have applied and have been accepted to exhibit, are unable to fund the costs of transport to attend the fair and also the costs of accommodation during their stay in Cape Town.
  2. There are a number of African musicians that we would like to invite to play at THAT ART PARTY- unfortunately we lack the funds to do so.
  3. By contributing to the fund you will be helping a deserving artist to attend the fair, to exhibit their works and to gain exposure to a mainstream market.
  4. THAT ART FAIR is hosted at the same time as the Cape Town Art Fair- there will be many international buyers in town, as well as gallerists, dealers, curators and directors of international galleries.
  5. THAT ART FAIR  2015 was enormously successful - one of the most important results was that artists from across the African continent were able to network with and meet other artists. Many of these artists' works were snapped up by collectors, gallerists and dealers.

THE IMPACT THAT THE CREATIVE INDUSTRIES CAN HAVE ON THE AFRICAN ECONOMIES:

The creative industries are one of the most valuable resources that Africa has to offer:
  1. Through creativity an artist  can support a family and a family can support a community. In turn a community can contribute to the economy of a country.
  2. Through creativity an artist can promote cultural understanding and tolerance.
  3. Through creativity an artist artist can be empowered to reach great heights.
  4. Through creativity an artist can promote gender equality, compassion and understanding.

IF YOU CAN'T MAKE A FINANCIAL CONTRIBUTION

  • Please help us by getting the word out about THAT ART FAIR and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to do this.
  • Wish us well and follow our progress online.
  • Like our Face Book page and follow us on Twitter- encourage your friends to do so too.

story:
Years ago, I saw a picture of a gorgeous man who had just come out of the ocean. He was wearing thin white shorts and that image of him in those wet trunks was so much more sexy than overtly sexual. Since then, I have been searching for a calendar that was more than just men in bathing suits (or hiding their treasure behind something) and less than the extremely pornographic.

The 2017 MEN OF SAN FRANCISCO calendar will pay homage to the aesthetic beauty of the male body when WET...partially clothed, as was the man who inspired this project for me, or nude, partially covered. Initially, I want to honor the Men of San Francisco because there just happen to be so many hot men who live in this city! However, my vision is to make a calendar series adding a new city/area each year and the plan is for the Men of Hawaii to be next!

Funding for this project will not only pay production costs for this year but will also provide seed money for future years. Up until now, I have been working on the project part-time and with limited resources. It would be ideal to be able to focus completely on this calendar and produce a quality product printed and ready for sale by June 2016, just in time for PRIDE!

There will be many perks available as this Campaign kicks off and more added as it continues toward the deadline of February 14, Valentine's Day. So visit this site often and check out the fun incentives that will be offered when you contribute such as autographed calendars, prints and posters, t-shirts, signed undies, and wait for it...dinner dates with the model of your choice!

Thank you so much in advance for your support. And please help get the word out about the HOT MEN that will be featured in the 2017 MEN OF SAN FRANCISCO Calendar by using the INDIEGOGO SHARE TOOLS!
