story:
The Fox Darkroom is a passionate community of film photography & darkroom enthusiasts based in the inner suburbs of Melbourne, Australia. 

Our dream is to expand our space into a gallery, artist studios & creative precinct. With your help, we can create the perfect space to celebrate great photography and inspire others to make art by hand. 

Our Story...

I'll never forget the first time I saw an image appear in the darkroom. The first blacks creeping into whites of the paper, the anticipation to see if it worked, the glow of the red lights, & above all the pride of producing something by hand. I was instantly addicted. It was that feeling all those years ago that made me fall in love with photography.   

Since then, the digital age has changed the way we produce photography in ways we couldn't have possibly imagined. There is no doubt some things have changed for the better, however, I couldn't help feeling some of the magic had disappeared.

In 2013, I felt the need to pick up my old film camera and start developing & printing in the darkroom again.  The first step was finding a suitable space to construct a small darkroom. At what can only be described as fate, I chanced upon the most amazing location in a beautiful old wool store in the heart of the industrial suburb of Kensington.  

Overnight my idea for building a personal darkroom grew into the dream of building a community darkroom where others could learn and share in my passion. 

I invested everything into constructing my dream. I was adamant that I not only wanted a darkroom with excellent facilities but also a space where people felt comfortable and inspired to create and share with others. 

This is how the space looked back in 2013..

We turned it into this!

The Fox Darkroom

In May 2014, I launched what may be Melbourne's most unique business, The Fox Darkroom. 

The name pays homage to one of the pioneers to of the photographic process - Henry Fox Talbot. 

Although it's still early days, The Fox Darkroom has grown heaps in the last year and a half.  We run regular workshops teaching the art of film photography and darkroom printing.  We also ran our first international photography workshop in Cambodia and have more planned for the future.  There is no room for egos within these walls, everybody has the right to learn. At the heart of The Fox Darkroom are our members. Currently, we have a small army of 63 darkroom enthusiasts from all walks of life.  I would never have predicted there were so many people out there who shared my love for film in Melbourne and around the world. Best of all, I get to watch the joy of others when they experience their first print appearing in the darkroom.

The quality of the work being produced at Fox is on the rise too. We can develop and print all formats of film from 35mm, 120, 4x5" right up to 8x10". Together with my members we hosted our first group exhibition in 2015 and a few of us (myself included) are working toward solo exhibitions. 

The Fox Darkroom & Gallery!

With your help, we're ready to take Fox to the next level. A beautiful space has become available adjoining The Fox Darkroom via the cobblestone laneway outside our door.  With 177 square meters of potential, we plan on transforming this space into the photographic home of Melbourne. 

The front of the space will be transformed into a cosy gallery full of industrial charm.  We envision this gallery having a strong focus on photographic art and traditional process.  With a little love, this space will be so warm and inviting. A great place to have a coffee, look at some quality art, & engage in conversation.   

The gallery would be available for group and solo exhibitions. We don't just see this space as a way to show great art but, more importantly, to bring our community together through photography.

The rear half of the space would be transformed into 6 artists studios and a communal workshop space/photographic studio.  We want to generate a hive of creative activity here. The in-house artists would help finance the day to day costs to maintaining the gallery. The workshop space/studio space will also be used as a way for us to give something back to the community. 

Floor plans

Design concepts

How the new space currently looks. Time to get to work!

What We Need 

Currently all profits have gone back into improving and getting the word out about The Fox Darkroom. We need your help in making this dream a reality.  We aim to raise $23,000 to finance the following:

  • Lighting for the gallery & artist studios
  • Electrical alternations
  • Artist studio partitions
  • Gallery partition 
  • Plumbing alterations
  • Kitchenette purcahse and installation
  • Internet installation 
  • Ventilation for artist studios 
  • Material costs (plaster, paint, etc)
  • Demolition and disposal of existing materials 
  • Renovations to existing walls 
  • Signage
  • Coffee machine
  • And so many more things!

Some of our Amazing Perks!

Luckily we have the best rewards going around! Some of these include; darkroom photographic prints, our highly sought after workshops, memberships, vintage cameras, film and international photographic workshops. 

Special thanks to our friends from Film Never Die, michaels cameras, Analogue Academy, Hillvale and Ilford Imaging for continuing to support our dream. We are so proud to be affilated with you guys! #filmisalive

The Fox Darkroom Badge Pins

Film Canister Key Rings

Analogue Academy Deal

'Film is Alive' t-shirts

Ilford film

Leather Camera Straps - The Urban

Leather Camera Straps - The Traveller

The Hillvale Pack

Darkroom Prints by Tom Goldner 

The Film Never Die Polaroid Pack

Nikon FM2 Starter Pack

Film Photography & Developing Workshops 

Darkroom Printing Workshops

International Photographic Workshops - Siem Reap, Cambodia

International Photographic Workshops - Tour du Mont Blanc

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand not everybody can contribute financially, here is how you can still help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about The Fox Darkroom & Gallery!
  • Volunteer with us. From helping with the build to manning our gallery, we need help. Contact tom@thefoxdarkroom.com.au to chat more.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share with your network.
  • Let us know if you or a friend are interested in occupying one of our spaces or exhibiting at The Fox Gallery.


Thanks and much love from all of your friends at The Fox Darkroom & Gallery!
story_txt:
The Fox Darkroom is a passionate community of film photography & darkroom enthusiasts based in the inner suburbs of Melbourne, Australia. 
Our dream is to expand our space into a gallery, artist studios & creative precinct. With your help, we can create the perfect space to celebrate great photography and inspire others to make art by hand. 

Our Story... I'll never forget the first time I saw an image appear in the darkroom. The first blacks creeping into whites of the paper, the anticipation to see if it worked, the glow of the red lights, & above all the pride of producing something by hand. I was instantly addicted. It was that feeling all those years ago that made me fall in love with photography.   
Since then, the digital age has changed the way we produce photography in ways we couldn't have possibly imagined. There is no doubt some things have changed for the better, however, I couldn't help feeling some of the magic had disappeared.
In 2013, I felt the need to pick up my old film camera and start developing & printing in the darkroom again.  The first step was finding a suitable space to construct a small darkroom. At what can only be described as fate, I chanced upon the most amazing location in a beautiful old wool store in the heart of the industrial suburb of Kensington.  
Overnight my idea for building a personal darkroom grew into the dream of building a community darkroom where others could learn and share in my passion. 
I invested everything into constructing my dream. I was adamant that I not only wanted a darkroom with excellent facilities but also a space where people felt comfortable and inspired to create and share with others. 


This is how the space looked back in 2013..

We turned it into this!


The Fox Darkroom

In May 2014, I launched what may be Melbourne's most unique business, The Fox Darkroom. 
The name pays homage to one of the pioneers to of the photographic process - Henry Fox Talbot. 
Although it's still early days, The Fox Darkroom has grown heaps in the last year and a half.  We run regular workshops teaching the art of film photography and darkroom printing.  We also ran our first international photography workshop in Cambodia and have more planned for the future.  There is no room for egos within these walls, everybody has the right to learn. At the heart of The Fox Darkroom are our members. Currently, we have a small army of 63 darkroom enthusiasts from all walks of life.  I would never have predicted there were so many people out there who shared my love for film in Melbourne and around the world. Best of all, I get to watch the joy of others when they experience their first print appearing in the darkroom.
The quality of the work being produced at Fox is on the rise too. We can develop and print all formats of film from 35mm, 120, 4x5" right up to 8x10". Together with my members we hosted our first group exhibition in 2015 and a few of us (myself included) are working toward solo exhibitions. 

The Fox Darkroom & Gallery!
With your help, we're ready to take Fox to the next level. A beautiful space has become available adjoining The Fox Darkroom via the cobblestone laneway outside our door.  With 177 square meters of potential, we plan on transforming this space into the photographic home of Melbourne. 

The front of the space will be transformed into a cosy gallery full of industrial charm.  We envision this gallery having a strong focus on photographic art and traditional process.  With a little love, this space will be so warm and inviting. A great place to have a coffee, look at some quality art, & engage in conversation.   
The gallery would be available for group and solo exhibitions. We don't just see this space as a way to show great art but, more importantly, to bring our community together through photography.
The rear half of the space would be transformed into 6 artists studios and a communal workshop space/photographic studio.  We want to generate a hive of creative activity here. The in-house artists would help finance the day to day costs to maintaining the gallery. The workshop space/studio space will also be used as a way for us to give something back to the community. 





Floor plans


Design concepts



How the new space currently looks. Time to get to work!
What We Need 
 Currently all profits have gone back into improving and getting the word out about The Fox Darkroom. We need your help in making this dream a reality.  We aim to raise $23,000 to finance the following:  Lighting for the gallery & artist studios
Electrical alternations
Artist studio partitions
Gallery partition 
Plumbing alterations
Kitchenette purcahse and installation
Internet installation 
Ventilation for artist studios 
Material costs (plaster, paint, etc)
Demolition and disposal of existing materials 
Renovations to existing walls 
Signage
Coffee machine
And so many more things!


Some of our Amazing Perks!
Luckily we have the best rewards going around! Some of these include; darkroom photographic prints, our highly sought after workshops, memberships, vintage cameras, film and international photographic workshops. 
Special thanks to our friends from Film Never Die, michaels cameras, Analogue Academy, Hillvale and Ilford Imaging for continuing to support our dream. We are so proud to be affilated with you guys! #filmisalive




The Fox Darkroom Badge Pins


Film Canister Key Rings


Analogue Academy Deal

'Film is Alive' t-shirts


Ilford film


Leather Camera Straps - The Urban

Leather Camera Straps - The Traveller



The Hillvale Pack

Darkroom Prints by Tom Goldner 



The Film Never Die Polaroid Pack


Nikon FM2 Starter Pack

Film Photography & Developing Workshops 

Darkroom Printing Workshops




International Photographic Workshops - Siem Reap, Cambodia



International Photographic Workshops - Tour du Mont Blanc
Other Ways You Can Help We understand not everybody can contribute financially, here is how you can still help:  Get the word out and make some noise about The Fox Darkroom & Gallery!
Volunteer with us. From helping with the build to manning our gallery, we need help. Contact tom@thefoxdarkroom.com.au to chat more. Use the Indiegogo share tools to share with your network.
Let us know if you or a friend are interested in occupying one of our spaces or exhibiting at The Fox Gallery.   Thanks and much love from all of your friends at The Fox Darkroom & Gallery!

story:
Update new fundraiser (active here)

https://igg.me/at/LRRCMusicVideoProgramFundraiser/x/3974173

Short Summary

Our mission is to provide a music & film program that gives youth the opportunity to build character, self-esteem, and learn about important issues affecting their communities while learning how to create and produce music and short documentaries in a fun, interactive & positive environment. We hope to inspire children to give back to their communities, learn the value of respecting one another, and the importance of community development.  Children participating in our program will gain valuable experience working as part of a production team and learn songwriting, videography, and storytelling skills.  The Youth will also learn how to create digital music, produce short films, and promote their work through the use of flyers, networking, and performing.  We will strive to provide quality instruction and help young, aspiring musicians and film makers actualize their dreams & potential.

Our Objectives

·  Create a lasting understanding of the music-making process

·  Teach & provide skill building techniques in songwriting and storytelling

·  Help youth develop a music video for their songs through narrative storytelling or montage

·  Help youth develop a short film documentary addressing important issues affecting the community

·  Teach youth to create & develop a promotional plan for showcasing the songs, videos, and documentaries they create and their end-of-program concert

·  Provide a final concert for participants to perform and showcase their work that engages the community 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $5,000 to purchase Laptops, Mics , Cameras ,Tripods , Midi Keyboards , Video editing / Music production Software so that we can provide the Youth with adequate equipment to gain a well-rounded experience in Music and Film production.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • You can Donate Audio or Video Equipment.
  • You can contact businesses about donating to our youth program 


Contact The Program Directors Below

Darrell Barber at - Blackdisciple2@gmail.com

Theresa Mahfood at - tcmahfood @gmail.com

Jasmine Thomas (Supervisor) at - jlthom19@gmail.com

This program is a part of the Lansdowne-Riverview Recreation Council in southwest Baltimore County,

story: -

9E2 in Seattle, October 2016

In 1966, Robert Rauschenberg and Billy Klüver, a Bell Labs engineer, created an event in New York City, “9 Evenings: Theatre & Engineering.” They paired ten engineers with ten artists and performers. The artists and performers included Rauschenberg and John Cage and choreographers Lucinda Childs and Deborah Hay, among others, and produced pioneering work that brought together art, science, and technology in compelling new ways.

In October 2016, we will commemorate the half-century anniversary of 9 Evenings with 9E2, a festival of art and technology to be held in Seattle. We’ll bring together artists, scientists, and engineers to both honor the traditions of 9 Evenings and investigate the artistic potentials of 21st century science and technology.

In 2016 we will draw together artists and scientists from across the globe, pairing them with artists, scientists and engineers from Seattle's vibrant art community and technology companies and schools. And we will create a deeply powerful celebration across Seattle.

Over the next year, we will be raising the funds needed to pay the artists and scientists, to produce the October event, to cover the many costs associated with a project of this scope.

We’re doing this initial campaign to raise the seed funding to get us started. We will spend these first funds on startup: to set up a business entity, pay web costs, begin further fundraising, and create the network of people and organizations that will make this whole project possible.

We would love to have you join us. As the coming year unfolds, we’ll be having parties, discussions, and workshops, all leading to the October event. You’ll note that our donation perks are about access: tickets to our test parties, and tickets and subscriptions to the October 2016 events.

We want to have you involved. Please give what you can. And spread the word about this exciting project. For more information about 9e2, check out our website: http://9e2seattle.com.

story: 106U Magazine est une revue d'art gratuite trimestrielle publiée par l'USINE 106U, une galerie autogérée de Montréal spécialisée dans l'art figuratif hors-normes. Jusqu'à maintenant, l'impression a été financée par des annonceurs, mais ils sont de plus en plus difficiles à trouver, c'est pourquoi je demande votre aide, afin de pouvoir maintenir ce projet admirable qui permet de diffuser le travail d'artistes extraordinaires par une publication gratuite de qualité. Merci.

story:
We need your help!!!

 

It's now time to repaint the Benton Harbor Black Lives Matter Street Mural. Last year over 300 of us came together and played a part. This year we must fix it up for the upkeep. We have to raise $3,300 for supplies and paint. By donating to this fund you will allow us to make this happen.. All donations are tax deductible. 

Let's do this Southwest Michigan!!!

story:
Thanks for viewing my IndieGoGo campaign! I’m Classy Bish Kate, creator of Sassfirmations!

Sassfirmations came to me one rough day when I was saying affirmations for my sanity but all I could think was “I really wish these had a cuss word or more of my sass.” I crafted a list for myself and started to feel my mood boosting. I started to post from my list and realized that many of my friends enjoyed my sayings and saved them for later. I started creating weekly free Sassfirmations for my community newsletter- The Classy Bish Collective.

I started to see my friends happier and spreading the sass and encouraging their friends to have better mindsets and to believe in themselves! It is such a cool self love movement to watch!

A year after creating Sassfirmations, I ordered in my first set of 100 decks and they quickly sold out. I was asked for more and to order in expansion packs but didn’t have anyone interested in crowdfunding. I tried to crowdfund myself and it fell flat without a platform that didn’t help me promote and share. Here we are!

Not only am I trying to order more of the OG Sassfirmations you see, but also decks focused on Parenting, Body Love, and Financial Abundance!
 

Want to know more?

To order in the next level of Sassfirmations, I need to raise $2000! This will cover all four decks, packaging, and gifts for early orders!

People who order by Sept 25th will receive a free Sassfirmation gift and free shipping when all four decks are ordered!

Receive bulk pricing discounts on orders over 5 of each deck! These cards are great to slip into customer orders or as gifts to your bish friends this holiday season!

if you order over 20 decks, I will mention you on my website with a big thank you! If you have a business, I will also link you!

If the goal isn’t reached, I will continue raising the funds but ordering decks in may take longer. Share this campaign with friends to help us get the decks in sooner!

 

The Impact

This project is my hearts work: empowering individuals to be their best and happiest selves.

I love the self love and confidence that has spread from thinking “this sentence could really use an f bomb”.

I am so happy the first 100 decks sold so quick and I can’t wait to get more Sassfirmations out in the world!
 

Risks & Challenges

While people have been asking for more, people have been wary too put money down as they want the product NOW. What they have failed to realize if they all put in, we could get the decks in FAST.

You can help with that by contributing and sharing the word!

I know with  my marketing degree combined with my sass, personal network, and your network this will be a walk in the park!
 

Other Ways You Can Help

I get being in a financial place you can’t contribute but sharing this campaign means THE WORLD TO ME! Share this link, my YouTube video, IGTV, and more to bring attention is SO HELPFUL,

I believe in Sassfirmations so much I even have free ones available! That’s how much I believe these can help change our self love routine and negative thoughts to positive ones.

story:
The 2017 Casa de las Américas colloquium is entitled "Memory and Border Conflicts," and will be held from the 22 to the 26 of May, 2017 in Havana, Cuba. This event will include the first major group exhibition of Virgin Islands artists outside of the territory in 10 years.  It is known to draw noted scholars, museum curators, and academics from around the world.

In the U.S. Virgin Islands, our government currently does not have any funding available for this type of project. In addition, the looming threat that the U.S. federal government seeks to increase military spending by $54 billion while altogether eliminating the National Endowment for the Arts does not bode well for national funding for the arts. 

We are asking for your assistance in being a sponsor of this unique opportunity for cultural exchange. Your sponsorship will help cover the costs of transporting the artists and artworks to Cuba.  In addition, we will be producing a catalog for the exhibition. The theme of the colloquium highlights the following three historical events: the centenaries of the transfer of the Danish West Indies from Denmark to the United States and the implementation of the Jones Act by the U.S. Congress granting US citizenship to Puerto Ricans, and the eightieth anniversary of the massacre on the Haitian-Dominican border.

The Gri Gri Project exhibition is entitled “My Islands Do Not Make a Nation.” The exhibition’s name is borrowed from St. Thomian writer Tiphanie Yanique’s poem, “Last Yanique Nation” published in her 2015 collection Wife. The title is also a reference to the ambivalent cosmopolitanism of life in one of the world’s last non-self-governing territories, an unincorporated territory of the United States. We hope to offer a glimpse into how some artists in the U.S.V.I. are approaching history and identity in 2017, the centennial year of the islands’ transfer from Denmark to the U.S, from one colonial power to another.

All of the artists are practicing contemporary artists from the Virgin Islands, where no art institution with a permanent collection exists, art criticism is nearly non-existent, and the historical record and visual archives are fragmented. This international creative exchange will help deepen understanding across cultures, and create ties between USVI artists and their counterparts in Cuba.  It will also better position the USVI to collaborate artistically with the greater Caribbean region. Your sponsorship of an artist, or financial assistance with art transportation, will ensure the success of this event. Our goal is to raise $7,000 by May 1, 2017. Any financial support you can provide will be greatly appreciated.

The Gri Gri Project:

The mission of the Gri Gri Project is the creation of interpretive exhibitions, critical writing, events and archives related to the cultural patrimony of the U.S. Virgin Islands. The team consists of curator Priscilla Hintz Rivera and writer David Knight Jr. The Gri Gri Project has been involved in arts-related projects and exhibitions in the Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, the United States, Aruba and Cuba. Exhibitions held in the U.S.V.I have included, "The Lady in Red Visits," “The Magnanimous Salon: A Celebration of the Contemporary Caribbean Baroque,” “An Ocean of Dignified Dust: The Legacy of the St. Thomas Coal Carriers,” “New Vernaculars,” “Camille Pissarro’s Journey,” and "100 Years of ..."

Casa de las Américas: http://www.casa.co.cu

Casa de las Américas is an organization that was founded by the Cuban Government in April 1959, for the purpose of developing and extending the socio-cultural relations with the countries of Latin America, the Caribbean and the rest of the world. Originally a publishing house and information center, it has developed into the best-known and most prestigious cultural institution in Cuba and the Caribbean.

The organization awards the Casa de las Américas Prize, one of the oldest and most prestigious prizes in Latin American literature. It also researches, supports, exhibits and publishes the work of writers, sculptors, musicians, visual artists and students of literature and the arts. Its official organ is the journal Casa de las Américas, published since 1961. The journal began as a literary magazine but has since become a general intellectual review with an equal focus on history and international politics. It also publishes Boletín, a journal specializing in Latin American music, Criterios, devoted to theory and criticism, and Analaes de Caribe, a scholarly journal for Caribbean specialists in all disciplines.

Participating Artists:

La Vaughn Belle, born in Trinidad and Tobago and raised on St. Croix, is an artist whose work has evolved from figurative and symbolic explorations in painting to a variety of modes that include video, performance, installation and public intervention projects.  Her work frequently responds to the questions surrounding the coloniality of the Virgin Islands, both in its present relationship to the U.S. and its past one to Denmark. http://www.lavaughnbelle.com

Shansi Miller, a painter born and raised on St. Thomas, creates large realist works in oil. Her narrative paintings are an ongoing exploration of the nuances of identity and history in the U.S. Virgin Islands. https://shansimiller.com

The four works selected for "My Islands Do Not Make a Nation" are large portraits of  Virgin Islanders depicted as protagonists in an epic creole mythology imagined by the artist. These paintings reference Western art history, biblical narratives and island folklore.

Jon Euwema, a St. Thomian visual artist and poet, creates critical works that often present a vision of island society filtered through an askew and irreverent sense of humor. These pieces, often utilizing found objects, are designed to suggest freedom from established power structures and institutional authority. http://arcthemagazine.com/arc/2015/06/jon-euwema-creole-tangentleman/

"My Islands Do Not Make a Nation" will feature three of Euwema's most recent multi-media pieces, which serve as commentary on social and political tensions in the Virgin Islands and the greater Caribbean region.

David Berg, born in Puerto Rico and raised on St. Croix, is a photographer whose work reaches unabashedly for the sublime and is heavily invested in a visual form of magical realism.

For "My Islands Do Not Make a Nation," the curators have selected three of Berg's underwater photographs that at once depict the ethereal nature of sub-marine light, Berg's interest in the human form, and narratives of rebellion intrinsic to Crucian identity. http://www.blackwoodimaging.com

Sigi Torinus, born and raised on St. Thomas, is an artist whose work is informed by her nomadic life. Her hybrid new media installations often combine sculptural elements with video, audio, and performance in an examination of migratory journeys, presence and absence, visibility and intangibility. Her art returns time and again to the themes of origin, departure, navigation and destination. http://sigi torinus

Janet Cook-Rutnik is an artist working on St. John since 1969. Over the past decade, her practice has shifted from painting, sculpture and printmaking to contemporary works incorporating video, photography and public art collaborations, often focusing on Virgin Islands history. http://www.cookrutnikart.vi

Cooper Joel Penn, born and raised in the Virgin Islands, is a photographer who has won awards for his work in the fashion and advertising industries in the United States. His recent artistic explorations involve celebrating, preserving and updating traditional Virgin Islands culture through image-making. Since childhood he has performed at events and festivals as a Mocko Jumbie, an art form he continues to pursue and explore. http://cooper penn

"My Islands Do Not Make a Nation" will feature three photographs from Penn's "Culture Goals" series, as well as a Mocko Jumbie performance by the artist.

Your sponsorship of an artist, or financial assistance with art transportation, will ensure the success of this event. Our goal is to raise $7,000 by May 1, 2017. Any financial support you can provide will be greatly appreciated.The Gri Gri Project:The mission of the Gri Gri Project is the creation of interpretive exhibitions, critical writing, events and archives related to the cultural patrimony of the U.S. Virgin Islands. The team consists of curator Priscilla Hintz Rivera and writer David Knight Jr. The Gri Gri Project has been involved in arts-related projects and exhibitions in the Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, the United States, Aruba and Cuba. Exhibitions held in the U.S.V.I have included, "The Lady in Red Visits," “The Magnanimous Salon: A Celebration of the Contemporary Caribbean Baroque,” “An Ocean of Dignified Dust: The Legacy of the St. Thomas Coal Carriers,” “New Vernaculars,” “Camille Pissarro’s Journey,” and "100 Years of ..."Casa de las Américas: http://www.casa.co.cuCasa de las Américas is an organization that was founded by the Cuban Government in April 1959, for the purpose of developing and extending the socio-cultural relations with the countries of Latin America, the Caribbean and the rest of the world. Originally a publishing house and information center, it has developed into the best-known and most prestigious cultural institution in Cuba and the Caribbean.The organization awards the Casa de las Américas Prize, one of the oldest and most prestigious prizes in Latin American literature. It also researches, supports, exhibits and publishes the work of writers, sculptors, musicians, visual artists and students of literature and the arts. Its official organ is the journal Casa de las Américas, published since 1961. The journal began as a literary magazine but has since become a general intellectual review with an equal focus on history and international politics. It also publishes Boletín, a journal specializing in Latin American music, Criterios, devoted to theory and criticism, and Analaes de Caribe, a scholarly journal for Caribbean specialists in all disciplines.Participating Artists:La Vaughn Belle, born in Trinidad and Tobago and raised on St. Croix, is an artist whose work has evolved from figurative and symbolic explorations in painting to a variety of modes that include video, performance, installation and public intervention projects.  Her work frequently responds to the questions surrounding the coloniality of the Virgin Islands, both in its present relationship to the U.S. and its past one to Denmark. http://www.lavaughnbelle.comShansi Miller, a painter born and raised on St. Thomas, creates large realist works in oil. Her narrative paintings are an ongoing exploration of the nuances of identity and history in the U.S. Virgin Islands. https://shansimiller.comThe four works selected for "My Islands Do Not Make a Nation" are large portraits of  Virgin Islanders depicted as protagonists in an epic creole mythology imagined by the artist. These paintings reference Western art history, biblical narratives and island folklore.Jon Euwema, a St. Thomian visual artist and poet, creates critical works that often present a vision of island society filtered through an askew and irreverent sense of humor. These pieces, often utilizing found objects, are designed to suggest freedom from established power structures and institutional authority. http://arcthemagazine.com/arc/2015/06/jon-euwema-creole-tangentleman/"My Islands Do Not Make a Nation" will feature three of Euwema's most recent multi-media pieces, which serve as commentary on social and political tensions in the Virgin Islands and the greater Caribbean region.David Berg, born in Puerto Rico and raised on St. Croix, is a photographer whose work reaches unabashedly for the sublime and is heavily invested in a visual form of magical realism.For "My Islands Do Not Make a Nation," the curators have selected three of Berg's underwater photographs that at once depict the ethereal nature of sub-marine light, Berg's interest in the human form, and narratives of rebellion intrinsic to Crucian identity. http://www.blackwoodimaging.comSigi Torinus, born and raised on St. Thomas, is an artist whose work is informed by her nomadic life. Her hybrid new media installations often combine sculptural elements with video, audio, and performance in an examination of migratory journeys, presence and absence, visibility and intangibility. Her art returns time and again to the themes of origin, departure, navigation and destination. http://sigi torinusJanet Cook-Rutnik is an artist working on St. John since 1969. Over the past decade, her practice has shifted from painting, sculpture and printmaking to contemporary works incorporating video, photography and public art collaborations, often focusing on Virgin Islands history. http://www.cookrutnikart.viCooper Joel Penn, born and raised in the Virgin Islands, is a photographer who has won awards for his work in the fashion and advertising industries in the United States. His recent artistic explorations involve celebrating, preserving and updating traditional Virgin Islands culture through image-making. Since childhood he has performed at events and festivals as a Mocko Jumbie, an art form he continues to pursue and explore. http://cooper penn"My Islands Do Not Make a Nation" will feature three photographs from Penn's "Culture Goals" series, as well as a Mocko Jumbie performance by the artist.

story:
Peace & Love

La mia vita negli ultimi anni è cambiata, ora è basata solamente sul desiderio di conoscere, di farmi emozionare dal mondo e dall'umanità, anche per questo motivo ho iniziato il mio progetto One Hundred Portraits, prima ancora che per scattare fotografie per vivere l'amore e la pace che scaturiscono da un rapporto breve ma intenso come una sessione di fotografie di ritratto. Fotografia consapevole. Mindful Portrait Photograpahy

  • Sono un artista ed un fotografo che ama il mondo, la vita, le persone.
  • Voglio realizzare un libro d'arte ed una mostra con 100 persone che vivono o passano dall'Italia
  • Il tuo contributo è importantissimo, perché aiuterai a far emergere storie di umanità e di bellezza.

Di cosa ho bisogno e cosa otterrete

Stampare un libro d'arte e realizzare una mostra in una location straordinaria ha un costo, l'ho calcolato in 10.000 euro

  • 100 stampe 70x100 attaccate su un supporto rigido 4500 euro circa
  • 200 Copie del libro stampate in due volumi firmati e numerati 3500 euro
  • Realizzazione dei portfolio 2000 euro

Voi potrete ottenere edizioni limitate dei libri, delle stampe e dei portfolio, tutti firmati.

Qui potrete trovare un impaginato con alcuni degli scatti selezionati. NON HA la veste grafica del libro, serve solo a tenervi aggionati sulle foto del progetto. Clicca qui!

L'impatto

Voi potrete fare la differenza dando un senso all'arte della relazione che si crea durante una sessione di ritratto.

  • Il progetto è importante perché racconta le persone che popolano o passano dall'Italia
  • Ho già realizzato progetti in giro per l'europa, il più importante è "Rebirth" (Italia, Spagna, Francia), totalmente auto-prodotto, è prevista una mostra a Parigi nel 2018
  • Sui ritratti sto a metà dell'opera (poco meno di 50 già selezionati, ritrarrò circa 200 persone per poter distillare il meglio), devo continuare ad esplorare, sto lavorando per fotografare dei migranti "di passaggio" per l'Italia.

Rischi e sfide

Al raggiungimento di 2500 euro darò via alla produzione del libro, con ulteriori 1000 euro creerò i portfolio. Solamente al raggiungimento del mio goal di 7500 darò via al progetto mostra.

  • Sono un artista, fotografo e direttore creativo con 25 anni e sono capace di gestire l'intero processo dallo scatto alla produione
  • La sfida è complessa perché dovrò realizzare almeno 200 ritratti per distillare il meglio, le persone più universali e più potenti dal punto di vista dello spettatore. Sono sicuro di riuscire perché ho un piano di lavoro intenso che mi obbliga a scattare almeno 3 volte la settimana

In che altro modo mi puoi aiutare

Diffondi questa campagna

  • Fallo sapere ai tuoi amici, condividila, invita a partecipare.
  • Condividila con semplicità attraverso i tools social di Indiegogo

And that's all!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Philip Young and I am a professional spiritual adviser and educator. With the help of photographer, videographer, and graphic designer Sasha Campbell, we have created a modern tarot deck as a tool to help you navigate the journey of life.  The deck has been completed, printed, and is ready for distribution. This deck can be a resource for daily meditation; a game to play for fun and thoughtful interactions with friends and new acquaintances; or a tool for spiritual counselors, psychologists, life coaches, and social workers.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $15000 to cover the purchase of 500 decks, boxes, and books for sale and distribution of the initial print run and funding to support a second print run.

  • The Tarot of the Human Experience uses modern black and white photography to capture archetypal situations that are common to our human experience.  This deck is a modern conceptualization centered on the core elements of classic tarot design: 22 major themes of human life (e.g., The Fool’s Journey), 4 suits related to the 4 elements, and 16 aspects of personality found in the court cards of the minor arcana).  The deck is visually accessible and ready to pick up and use for those new to tarot.  It is also designed with a scholarly underpinning that can engage professional counselors and people interested in complex systems of thought. See sample images of the cards at: http://www.blackunykorn.com/tarot-of-the-human-...
  • As a thank you for your support, a variety of perks ranging from a copy of the Tarot of the Human Experience to tarot tutoring to a year of tarot readings are available. Check out all the perks!
  • The Tarot of the Human Experience has 98 cards, instead of the traditional 78.  The 20 extra cards are reversed meanings for cards numbered 6 to 10 of the minor arcana suits. For example, the 9 of Water is named Accepting and the 9 of Water reversed is named Rejecting).
  • The Tarot of the Human Experience is printed on card stock that is equivalent to playing cards. Each card measures 2 3/4 inches by 4 1/4 inches, which makes the deck very easy to shuffle and hold.
  • This deck breaks with a number of traditions that are common to most modern tarot decks.  It is not a Rider-Waite, Golden Dawn, or Thoth tarot "knock off"; most decks published today mimic these older decks, mostly with changes in art and some modern modifications to the originating themes.  This deck is revolutionary. Old themes and rigid adherence to tarot tradition keep tarot cards out of mainstream use.  This deck has the potential to push tarot into the mainstream by using modern black and white photography and through the purposeful rejection of limiting and charged references (e.g., pentacles, swords, queens, kings, Hierophant, Tower) for more common and accessible ones (e.g., practical life, creativity; life professions: the Engineer, the Farmer; and deep common themes we all experience: Sharing Knowledge with Others, Sudden/Unexpected/Dramatic Change).  Except for the 78 card structure (4 suits, 22 trumps) the deck is a new vision for the tarot.

The Impact

Tarot has an interesting history as a card game that has evolved into a spiritual and psychological tool.  With this deck I asked and answered the following question: "What would a tarot deck look like if, first and foremost, it was designed to be a spiritual and psychological tool, not a card game?"  I have used the tarot and oracle cards to help myself and others navigate difficult and challenging life situations since 1989 (when I purchased my first deck; I did my first professional reading in 1992).  I have seen firsthand the powerful positive impact this tool can have in my life and other people's lives.  Properly done tarot readings change people's lives for the better; I make a substantial portion of my living seeing proof of this outcome on a weekly basis.  Even if the deck is used solely for personal purposes, you will be astounded at how helpful it can be to own and use it regularly or when you encounter a difficult circumstance in your life or need to break out of a stagnant pattern.

Risks & Challenges

This project is fully self-published; these funds are not being used to pay a publisher, but rather to pay back the creators and make a future payment to the companies printing the decks, boxes, and books.  We are hopeful that a successful campaign will either make the deck attractive to a world-wide distributor or show us that we can go forward as our own world-wide distributor. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with as many people as you can.  This deck has been designed to play a role in everyone's daily life, to help build and maintain spiritual and psychological health.  Definitely make some noise about this campaign, and please use the Indiegogo share tools!
